Abstract: Evaluates project to integrate family planning (FP) education into developing country (DC) home economics programs.  Evaluation covers the period 6/72-1/77 and is based on document review, visits to seven DC's, and interviews with staff at AID/W and at headquarters of the American Home Economics Association (AHEA), the contractor. The project has been moderately successful.  AHEA has developed working contracts with 28 countries, eight of which have carried out significant amounts of project activities.  Of these, progress -- which has depended on host country governmental and cultural support and the availability of solid institutional mechanisms -- has been greatest in Korea, Thailand, and the Philippines; least in Sierra Leone and Ghana; and moderate in Jamaica, Panama, and Nepal. Progress in integrating FP education into university home economics programs (where students, however, are relatively few) has been excellent, and has been good in vocational and teachers' colleges.  Rural outreach has been most successful in Korea, the Philippines, and Thailand. Educational radio messages and contacts with parents of day care children have been moderately successful. On the negative side, community development and extension services have been underutilized; recordkeeping is inadequate; few DC home economists have become actively involved; chronic shortages of teaching and reference materials exist; project leadership is too often concentrated in a few dynamic personalities; and assistance from AHEA headquarters to field workers and host country funding have been insufficient.  Planning has been hampered by AHEA's failure to utilize DC home economist advisory committees and by A.I.D.'s failure to provide indepth analyses of country environments. The project should be extended for 5 years, provided AHEA: increase its headquarters staff to provide stronger field management; increase the involvement of DC home economics associations; determine, with the help of A.I.D.'s Office of Population (DS/POP) whether a suitable environment for the project exists before beginning work in a given country; and place more emphasis on assessing DC needs for teaching and outreach materials and on helping to obtain these materials.

Abstract: Evaluates project to enhance Virgina State College's (VSC) capacity to provide expertise in general and agricultural economics to LDC poor farmers and rural businesses. Special evaluation covers the period 6/72-3/76 and is based on a team review of project documents and a visit to VSC. The 211 (d) grant has been the main factor in initiating and maintaining at VSC a graduate (Masters) program - basic to an increased VSC research capacity - in economics with emphasis on economic development and agricultural economics. Also, since the grant, VSC has internationalized its undergraduate program and is considering merging the schools of economics and agricultural economics. Grant funds are currently supporting eight undergraduate and seven graduate students. The grant's central focus was to allow VSC's Bureau of Economic Research and Development (BERD) to expand from domestic to overseas research. Since the grant, BERD's full-time faculty have increased from one to five. Still, short-term consultancies have been limited, although two more BERD faculty will be hired shortly. No possibility for long-term consultancies is apparent. Nonetheless, BERD has not moved rapidly enough beyond domestic research (in south central Virginia) to determine the relevancy of this research to A.I.D., although BERD's interest areas - agriculture, marketing, management, and manpower and production - are of special interest to A.I.D. Only in the last year has BERD established a formal LDC linkage, with Ghana's University of Science and Technology in Ghana. Collaboration with other 211 (d) grant institutions has been less than expected. It is recommended that: the grant be extended 2 years to allow VSC to develop further its project-related capabilities; A.I.D. (especially the Bureau for Africa) become more involved in guiding VSC research and examine the training possibilities offered by VSC's domestic research programs; VSC refine its work plans and develop a logframe for the current grant's final year; and that sustained collaboration be encouraged among the academic institutions, A.I.D. offices, other donor agencies, and the U.S. Department of Agriculture involved in international economic and especially agricultural development.

Abstract: THE RESULTS OF AN EVALUATIVE STUDY OF GUATEMALAN RURAL COOPERATIVES RECEIVING ASSISTANCE THROUGH AID. THE OBJECTIVES WERE TO DETERMINE MORE PRECISELY THE CHARACTERISTICS OF BENEFICIARIES OF THE PROGRAMS; THE KINDS, QUALITIES, AND IMPACTS OF SERVICES PROVIDED; THE RELEVANCE AND VIABILITY OF THE INSTITUTIONS OPERATING THE PROGRAMS; THE COST/BENEFIT RELATIONS OF PROJECT ACHIEVEMENTS; MAJOR ISSUES RELEVANT TO PRESENT AND FUTURE SUCCESS OF PROGRAMS; AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FUTURE PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT. THE REPORT PRESENTS SIX GENERAL FINDINGS OF THE STUDY: (1) IN SIX YEARS GUATEMALA HAS DEVELOPED A LARGE AND STRONG COOPERATIVE MOVEMENT SERVING SOME 50,000 FARMERS. THIS IS 10 PERCENT OF ALL FARMERS, AND 18 PERCENT OF FARMERS IN THE ALTIPLANO, WHERE THE BULK OF EFFORT HAS BEEN CONCENTRATED. (2) RURAL COOPERATIVES SUPPORTED BY AID ARE REACHING ALMOST EXCLUSIVELY INDIVIDUALS WITHIN THE LOW-INCOME TARGET GROUP.  (3) THE AID INVESTMENT IN GRANT AND LOAN FUNDS HAS BEEN GENERALLY WELL UTILIZED. (4) THE PROGRAMS HAVE BEEN MEETING THE AID OBJECTIVES OF ASSISTING SMALL FARMERS TO INCREASE PRODUCTION, IMPROVE LIVING STANDARDS, PARTICIPATE IN NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND INCREASE RURAL INCOMES; AND OF ASSISTING RURAL COOPERATIVES TO BECOME VIABLE, SELF-SUFFICIENT INSTITUTIONS. (5) THE PRINCIPAL SHORTCOMINGS HAVE BEEN OVER-CONCENTRATION ON SUPPLYING CREDIT AND FERTILIZER, WITH UNDER-CONCENTRATION ON TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, CROP DIVERSIFICATION AND MARKETING IMPROVEMENTS. (6) GUATEMALAN COOPERATIVES HAVE A LARGE POTENTIAL FOR FURTHER GROWTH IN MEMBERSHIP AND FOR BROADENING THE RANGE OF SERVICES OFFERED. THEY ALSO ENJOY FOR THE FIRST TIME IN GUATEMALAN HISTORY THE STRONG SUPPORT OF THE NATIONAL GOVERNMENT.

Abstract: IN MARCH 1974, A STUDY WAS MADE OF WHETHER TECHNIQUES COULD BE DEVISED TO MEASURE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF PARTICIPANT TRAINING BY THE IMPACT OF RETURNED PARTICIPANTS ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF THEIR COUNTRIES. THE CONCLUSION TO THIS WAS AFFIRMATIVE AND TOOK THE FORM OF A PROTOTYPE METHODOLOGY FOR CARRYING OUT SUCH ASSESSMENTS. THIS REPORT IS OF THE METHODS AND PROCEDURES DESIGNED FOR FUTURE FIELD ASSESSMENTS. TWO SECTORS (AGRICULTURE AND ECONOMIC PLANNING) WERE EXAMINED, AND THE SUBSTANTIVE FINDINGS FOR EACH ARE PRESENTED HERE. IT IS IMPORTANT TO NOTE, HOWEVER, THAT THE REAL OBJECTIVE OF THESE FINDINGS WAS METHODOLOGICAL, NOT SUBSTANTIVE. THAT THE PARTICIPANTS IN THESE TRAINING PROGRAMS HAVE HAD A SIGNIFICANT IMPACT ON THEIR COUNTRIES' DEVELOPMENT IS NOT SURPRISING, AND IT IS THE OVERWHELMING CONSENSUS IN BOTH THE UNITED STATES AND ABROAD, THAT THE USAID PARTICIPANT TRAINING EFFORT HAS BEEN A VERY PRODUCTIVE FORM OF TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. RATHER, WHAT IS NEW IN THIS STUDY IS THE SPECIFICITY OF THE DEFINITION OF IMPACT AND THE DEMONSTRATION OF SPECIFIC LINKAGES TO TRAINING.

Abstract: THE FINDINGS OF A STUDY OF THE STATUS AND FUTURE DEVELOPMENT POTENTIAL OF THE EASTERN RURAL DEVELOPMENT ORGANIZATION (ORD) IN UPPER VOLTA. FROM MID-OCTOBER TO MID-DECEMBER OF 1975, THE MSU TEAM GATHERED INFORMATION AND CONDUCTED FIELD VISITS. THE REPORT PRESENTS ITS ECONOMIC ANALYSIS AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT; AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION, MARKETING, AND CREDIT; LIVESTOCK; STAFF TRAINING; AND THE ORD ANNUAL PLAN. THE RECOMMENDATIONS CONCERN INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT ROAD IMPROVEMENTS AND THE BEST MEANS OF ACCOMPLISHING THEM. THIS IS THE TOP PRIORITY IN DEVELOPMENT. THE LACK OF ROAD TRANSPORTATION HAS MULTIPLE AND INTERRELATED NEGATIVE EFFECTS ON THE POSSIBLE DEVELOPMENT OF THE REGION. RECOMMENDATIONS CONCERNING DEVELOPMENT OF MARKETING PROGRAMS INCLUDE (1) RAPID ORD REACTION TO NATIONAL MARKETING AND FINANCIAL POLICY DECISIONS; (2) RATIONALIZATION AND IMPROVEMENT IN MARKETING MANAGEMENT, LOGISTICS, AND FINANCIAL OPERATIONS; (3) THE STRENGTHENING OF EFFECTIVE DEMAND THROUGH DEVELOPMENT OF NEW MARKET OUTLETS; AND (4) THE NEED TO INITIATE BASELINE STUDIES OF PRESENT MARKETING SYSTEM FOR BASIC CASH AND FOOD CROPS, ALONG WITH COLLECTION OF BASIC MARKET INFORMATION. RECOMMENDATIONS CONCERNING AGRICULTURAL CREDIT INCLUDE (1) THE NEED FOR ORD TO DEVELOP A FIVE-YEAR, VERSATILE CREDIT PROGRAM; (2) LIMITING CREDIT FOR ANIMAL TRACTION EQUIPMENT TO HV2A AND HV2B EQUIPMENT; (3) EXTENDING MEDIUM-TERM CREDIT FOR THE 1976 CROP SEASON TO PAYSANS ENCADRES IN THE COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT VILLAGES AND THE FOUR INTENSIVE ZONES; (4) PREPARATION OF EXTENSION CHECKLISTS ON HOW TO EVALUATE THE DEBT-CARRYING CAPACITY OF FARMERS AND COLLECTIVE ORGANIZATIONS; (5) ESTABLISHING A CREDIT SYSTEM FOR TRAINED BLACKSMITHS; AND (7) UNDERTAKING TECHNICAL AND ECONOMIC FEASIBILITY STUDIES TO DETERMINE POSSIBILITIES FOR SMALL-SCALE AGRICULTURAL PROCESSING ACTIVITIES. RECOMMENDATIONS CONCERNING LIVESTOCK MANAGEMENT DEAL WITH ACQUISITION OF INNOCULATION EQUIPMENT, ORGANIZATION OF CASH BEEF MARKETS, PILOT DEMONSTRATIONS OF FEED SUPPLEMENT PROGRAMS, SURVEYS OF LAND USE AND PARASITE INFESTATIONS, OBSERVATION OF DAHOMEY ANIMAL TRACTION ASSOCIATIONS, THE GATHERING OF LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION AND MARKETING INFORMATION, AND GENERATION OF GUIDELINES FOR FARM PROTOTYPES. RECOMMENDATIONS CONCERNING TRAINING CONCERN INVESTMENTS IN TRAINING INSTITUTIONS, ESTABLISHMENT OF A LOW-COST TRAINING CENTER IN EACH SECTOR HEADQUARTERS, INITIATION OF WORKSHOPS AT THE SECTOR LEVEL, DEVELOPMENT

Abstract: NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMS HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED FOR MANY YEARS IN MANY COUNTRIES, BUT THEIR ACTUAL EFFECTIVENESS HAS NOT BEEN ESTABLISHED, PARTLY FOR WANT OF A SIMPLE AND EFFECTIVE SET OF METHODS FOR EVALUATING THEM. THIS IS WHY USAID DEVELOPED AN EXPERIMENTAL FIELD GUIDE FOR CONDUCTING SUCH EVALUATIONS. FROM 1973 TO 1975 THE FIELD GUIDE WAS TESTED IN BRAZIL ON THREE KINDS OF NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMS: PERSON-TO-PERSON, GROUP TEACHING, AND MASS MEDIA. THE EVALUATION METHODOLOGY WAS APPLIED TO THREE BRAZILIAN PROGRAMS: SERVICO SOCIAL DA INDUSTRIA (SESI), THE ASSOCIACAO BRASILEIRA DE CREDITO E ASSISTENCIA RURAL (ABCAR), AND THE SUPERINTENDENCIA NACIONAL DO ABASTECIMENTO (SUNAB). THIS REPORT DISCUSSES THAT ACTIVITY AND PRESENTS CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS BASED UPON IT. THE REVISED FIELD GUIDE WAS PUBLISHED IN JUNE, 1975. THE RECOMMENDATIONS DERIVING FROM THE DEVELOPMENT WORK, CONFERENCES WITH A PANEL OF EXPERTS, AND EXPERIENCES IN THE FIELD DEMONSTRATION ARE SUMMARIZED BELOW: FURTHER FIELD APPLICATIONS SHOULD BE CARRIED OUT TO ENSURE THE UTILITY OF THE METHODOLOGY FOR COST-EFFECTIVENESS COMPARISONS. THE UNDER-FIVE TARGET AUDIENCE SHOULD BE GIVEN PRIORITY, AND SITES SELECTED SHOULD BE IN COUNTRIES LESS DEVELOPED THAN BRAZIL. THE USERS OF THE GUIDE SHOULD BE ORIENTED AND TRAINED. FURTHER APPLICATIONS OF THE METHODOLOGY SHOULD DETERMINE THE NEED FOR ALTERNATIVE AND LESS SOPHISTICATED METHODS, AND SHOULD EXPLORE POSSIBLE TECHNIQUES. CONSIDERATION SHOULD BE GIVEN TO DEVELOPING SUPPLEMENTS TO THE FIELD GUIDE TO PROVIDE PROCEDURAL MODELS FOR MEASURES OF ADDITIONAL FOOD BEHAVIORS SUCH AS FOOD ACQUISITION, STORAGE, AND PREPARATION. A SUMMARY HANDBOOK SHOULD BE DEVELOPED FOR PROGRAM ADMINISTRATORS AND PLANNERS. AID SHOULD PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO GOVERNMENTS AND TO VOLUNTARY AND INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS THAT MAY REQUEST SUCH HELP IN EVALUATING THEIR NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMS.

Abstract: THE EVALUATION IS BASED ON STUDIES OF NINE AID PROGRAMS IN ECUADOR AND HONDURAS. THE EVALUATOR DISCUSSES AND MAKES RECOMMENDATIONS ON SMALL FARMER GROUPS, GROUPS AND LAND ACQUISITION, FEDERATIONS AND OTHER GROUP-ASSISTING ORGANIZATIONS, CREDIT UNIONS AND THEIR FEDERATIONS, CREDIT PROGRAMS FOR SMALL FARMER GROUPS, SELF-SUFFICIENCY AND AID SUPPORTED ORGANIZATIONS, INTER-AGENCY COORDINATION, AND MONITORING AND IMPLEMENTATION OF SMALL FARMER GROUP PROJECTS.  SMALL FARMER ORGANIZATIONS TEND TO DO BETTER WHEN THEY ORGANIZE AROUND A CONCRETE GOAL. AID'S PROGRAMS TO ORGANIZE SMALL FARMER ORGANIZATIONS HAVE HAD CONSIDERABLY LESS IMPACT THAN THEY MIGHT HAVE. AID-FINANCED ORGANIZATIONS PLAYED IMPORTANT ROLES AS BROKERS. CREDIT UNIONS AND THEIR FEDERATIONS, IN CONTRAST TO COOPERATIVE FEDERATIONS, HAVE BEEN MORE SUCCESSFUL CASES OF AID INSTITUTION BUILDING, AND THEY HAVE DONE BETTER THAN OTHER FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS AT GETTING CREDIT TO SMALL FARMERS. THE EVALUATOR MADE 51 RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDING: (1)AID SHOULD TAKE A SEQUENTIAL OR EVOLUTIONARY APPROACH TO SMALL FARMER ORGANIZING. IT SHOULD FOCUS ON CERTAIN ORGANIZATION-BUILDING TASKS, RATHER THAN ON CERTAIN ORGANIZATIONAL FORMS; AND (2)AID SHOULD TAKE MORE ADVANTAGE OF THE SMALL FARMER'S INTEREST IN ORGANIZING TEMPORARILY TO ACHIEVE CERTAIN LIMITED AND CONCRETE GOALS.

Abstract: In 1971, the Ivory Coast implemented a nationwide educational system reform designed to improve the reach and quality of educational offerings. A primary component of this reform is the intensive utilization of educational television (ETV) in primary schools. This report evaluates the Ivory Coast's system of ETV program production. Plans for broadcast and production output from the ETV Complex in Bouake have been consistently more ambitious than achievements. Comparing planning documents to actual results indicates that the system is presently operating at only 60% efficiency. The long run average production costs are estimated under three different assumptions, one representing the present situation and the others positing efficiency improvements. In any case, the Ivorian project seems relatively expensive when compared with other projects, although the large actual and projected student enrollments reduce the per student costs to reasonable levels. The different stages in the process of program production and the interactions between the three principal actors in the process -- the producer, the printed support materials writer, and the director -- are described in detail. This forms an essential background to the consideration of four key program production issues. The system lacks sufficient organization and planning to ensure that even the most straightforward necessities of program production are accomplished. There has been inadequate training of Ivorians to take over the management and operation of the ETV Complex, planned for 1980. Efforts to set up a feedback and evaluation system have been impeded by the heavy demands of the production schedule. The fourth issue, film versus videotape, is nonproblematic, but is included for the benefit of other LDCs. The authors conclude that the basic ingredients for a good ETV program production system are in place, and now that the initial coverage of the full six grades of primary school is almost complete, more time should be devoted to making improvements in the efficiency with which the system operates before the system is further expanded. A 20-item bibliography of French- and English-language references (1967-76) is included.

Abstract: UNDER A TWO-YEAR AGREEMENT, AID IS TO PROVIDE $150,000 ANNUALLY FOR THE PURCHASE OF MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT FOR COMMUNITY SELF-HELP RURAL WATER SUPPLY PROJECTS IDENTIFIED FOR ASSISTANCE BY THE CARE/KENYA STAFF. THE PURPOSE OF THE WATER DEVELOPMENT PROJECT IS TO RENDER WATER MORE ACCESSIBLE TO RURAL INHABITANTS WHO CONSTITUTE THE POOREST MAJORITY IN KENYA. TO DATE, 25 INDIVIDUAL PROJECTS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED FOR ASSISTANCE. FOR TEN OF THESE, CARE MATERIALS HAVE BEEN INSTALLED. HOWEVER, IT IS NOT CLEAR WHETHER ALL THE SYSTEMS TO WHICH CARE HAS CONTRIBUTED ARE AS YET DELIVERING SECURE WATER, NOR WHETHER THE PORTION OF THE SYSTEM WHICH CARE HAS SUPPLIED IS AS YET OPERATIONAL. CAREFUL EXAMINATION OF THE DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS PROJECT INDICATES THAT IT WAS NAIVELY DESIGNED AND IMPERFECTLY IMPLEMENTED AND THAT THE GOVERNMENT OF KENYA, CARE, AND USAID ARE IN ALMOST EQUAL MEASURE RESPONSIBLE FOR A NOBLE IMPULSE BEING UNDERMINED BY POOR MANAGEMENT. THE EFFORT TO MEET THE OBJECTIVE OF IMPLEMENTING THIRTY PROJECTS ANNUALLY HAS RESULTED IN A PROLIFERATION OF WIDELY-SCATTERED AND VERY DIFFERENT TYPES OF WATER SUPPLY PROJECTS, RENDERING MANAGERIAL CONTROL DIFFICULT AND COSTLY.

Abstract: FIRST IN-DEPTH EVALUATION OF FY71-FY79 AGRICULTURAL MARKETING DEVELOPMENT PROJECT IN TANZANIA ASSESSES IMPACT OF TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDED THROUGH JULY 1976. PROJECT DESIGNED TO ASSIST GOT IN ESTABLISHMENT OF MARKETING & PROCESSING INSTITUTIONS TO ASSURE FOOD SUPPLY & RELIABLE MARKETS. AID-RECRUITED TEAM EVALUATED PROGRESS IN TERMS OF ORIGINAL PROJECT OBJECTIVES BUT FOUND ASSESSMENT HAMPERED BY LACK OF QUANTIFIABLE INDICATORS IN PROJECT DESIGN. PROGRESS DEEMED SIGNIFICANT IN 1) USE OF AGRICULTURAL COOPERATIVE DVLP INTERNATIONAL  (ACDI) FINANCE & MGMT,ECONOMIC ANALYSIS,MARKETING,AND STORAGE & TRANSPORT SPECIALISTS; 2) IMPROVEMENT IN ACCOUNTING PRACTICES; 3) REDUCTION IN PRODUCE LOSSES; 4) PRICE PHASING OF CROPS TOWARD EXPORT PARITY. PROGRESS JUDGED INSUFFICIENT OR INDETERMINATE IN 1) REDUCTION OF PER UNIT MARKETING COSTS; 2) POTENTIAL EXPORT DVLP FOR NON-TRADITIONAL EXPORT PRODUCTS; 3) DVLP OF FULL-COST ACCOUNTING BASIS FOR ESTABLISHING PRODUCER PRICES. WHILE PROGRESS TOWARD PROJECT PURPOSE IS REGARDED SIGNIFICANT,ACHIEVEMENT OF SECTOR GOAL OF TANZANIAN SELF-SUFFICIENCY IN FOODSTUFFS WAS FORESTALLED BY SEVERE 1974-75 DROUGHT. PROJECT JUDGED AS MAKING ITS MOST SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION IN GOT/USAID/PROJECT SPECIALISTS TEAMWORK IN SUCCESSFULLY COUNTERNG ACUTE FOOD CRISIS. PROJECT FOUND TO BE HAMPERED BY AID/W IMPLEMENTATION & CONTRACT NEGOTIATION DELAYS,ACDI RECRUITMENT DELAYS & FAILURE TO REPLACE VITAL ECONOMIC SPECIALIST, GOT DISSOLUTION OF NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS BOARD(NAPB)TO WHICH SPECIALISTS ASSIGNED, AND SHORTAGES OF TRAINED MANPOWER IN KEY AREAS AS WELL AS IN VITAL EQUIPMENT/SUPPLIES. SPECIALISTS DOWNGRADED TO ADVISORS IN NATIONAL MILLING CORP(NMC)PERFORMING TASKS NOT WITHIN PROJECT SCOPE;USAID-SUBMITTED PROP REFLECTING NAPB DISSOLUTION & SPECIALIST ROLE CHANGES NOT ACTED UPON BY AID/W. TEAM RECOMMENDS AMENDING PROJECT TO REFLECT TEAM REPORT & USAID-PROPOSED REVISIONS,CLOSER AID/ACDI LIASON WITH PROMPT REPLACEMENT OF PROJECT ECONOMIST & THE PHASING-OUT OF OTHER SPECIALISTS UPON TOUR COMPLETION. EVALUATORS RECOMMEND NEW PROJECT INPUTS IN FORM OF SHORT-TERM ACTIVITIES IN FINANCE/ACCOUNTING & TRAINING FOR STAFF DEVELOPMENT.

Abstract: THE NATIONAL MAIZE PLAN (NMP) APPEARS TO BE HANDLING THE LOGISTICAL PROBLEM OF SUPPLYING VILLAGES WITH INPUTS IN A REASONABLY ORGANIZED AND EFFICIENT WAY. THE PROGRAM WAS SUCCESSFUL IN TEACHING FARMERS ABOUT GOOD MAIZE PRODUCTION PRACTICES. HOWEVER, IN BOTH CONCEPTION AND IMPLEMENTATION, THE PROGRAM SUFFERS FROM SOME CRITICAL FLAWS. AT NO POINT IN THE PROGRAM IS SERIOUS CONDIDERATION GIVEN TO DEVELOPING A LOCAL CAPACITY TO CONTINUE THE PROJECT FUNCTIONS. AS IT NOW OPERATES, THE PROJECT REINFORCES A PATTERN OF PASSIVE VILLAGE DEPENDENCY ON THE GOVERNMENT. THE PROBLEMS CONNECTED WITH PAYING FOR INPUTS SHOULD BE CAREFULLY REVIEWED. THIS INCLUDES THE ECONMONIC RETURN TO INPUTS AT UNSUBSIDIZED PRICES, THE EXTENSION OF CREDIT, AND IMPROVING THE TRANSPORT AND MARKETING SYSTEMS. LOCAL PEOPLE AND LOCAL CONDITIONS MUST BE INCLUDED AS A CENTRAL CONSIDERATION OF THE PROJECT. RECOMMENDATIONS MADE TO FARMERS MUST BE LOCALLY APPROPRIATE. PACKAGE SALES MUST BE LOCALLY EVALUATED. THE LOCAL NEED FOR CREDIT SHOULD BE EVALUATED. THE EXTENSION EFFORT SHOULD BE ADOPTED TO LOCAL CONDITIONS. LOCAL PEOPLE MUST BE INVOLVED IN THE PLANNING AND OPERATION OF THE PROJECT. UNLESS THESE THINGS ARE DONE, NMP WILL BE JUST ANOTHER ONESHOT BANDAID PROJECT WHICH CONTRIBUTED LITTLE OR NOTHING TO DEVELOPMENT.

Abstract: THE RURAL DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT (RDD) HAS MOVED FROM A FLEDGLING ORGANIZATION TO A VIABLE AND REPUTABLE RURAL WORKS AGENCY. IT HAS INITIATED SYSTEMATIC ATTEMPTS TO IMPLEMENT INTEGRATED RURAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS IN FIVE PILOT REGIONS OF THE COUNTRY. IT HAS NOT ACCOMPLISHED ITS OBJECTIVES BOTH IN RURAL WORKS AND IN INTEGRATED RURAL DEVELOPMENT TO THE LIMIT OF ITS OWN CAPABILITIES, TO THE DESIRES OF THE AID MISSION,OR TO THE INTENT OF THE ORIGINAL AID PROJECT DESIGNERS. IT IS, HOWEVER, A SIGNIFICANT FORCE FOR CHANGE AND MODERNIZATION. BEGINNING IN APRIL 1976, RDD EXPECTS TO COMPLETE 70 RURAL WORKS. THESE PROJECTS HAVE BEEN SURVEYED, DESIGNED, APPROVED, AND CONSTRUCTION TEAMS HAVE BEEN ASSIGNED TO THE FIELD. WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF USAID IN THE RURAL WORKS PROJECT PILOT PHASE, DESIGN STANDARDS AND CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED AND GENERALLY ADHERED TO. THE EVALUATION CONTAINS: (1)A SUMMARY OF PROJECT PERFORMANCE; (2)AN ASSESSMENT OF THE PROGRESS OF AID SUPPORT TO THE RURAL WORKS COMPONENT OF RDD AGAINST THE ORIGINAL INTENT OF THE PROJECT DESIGNERS; (3)SPECIFIC FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS ON A LARGE NUMBER OF ISSUES AND ASSUMPTIONS; AND (4)AN APPROACH TO DISTRICT DEVELOPMENT IN AFGHANISTAN. THE EVALUATORS RECOMMEND THAT AID SUPPORT TO THE RURAL WORKS COMPONENT OF RDD BE CONTINUED.

Abstract: THIS EVALUATION SEEKS TO DIAGNOSE EXISTING PROBLEMS AND ISSUES WHICH AFFECT PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION AND TO OFFER SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THEIR RESOLUTION. THE PROJECT PLANNING CONCEPTS AND OBJECTIVES REMAIN SOUND. INCREASINGLY CLOSE COMMUNICATIONS AND A DEVELOPING TEAM SPIRIT NOW CHARACTERIZE THE WORKING RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN HELMAND-ARGHANDAB VALLEY AUTHORITY (HAVA) AND USAID. REASONABLE AGREEMENT EXISTS ON OBJECTIVES, ALTHOUGH PRIORITIES SEEM TO DIFFER. GENERAL PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION WAS DELAYED BY LACK OF FORCEFUL, CONTINUOUS, FULL-TIME MANAGEMENT OF THE PART OF USAID. DRAIN CONSTRUCTION COMPLETED TO DATE HAS BEEN OF ACCEPTABLE STANDARDS AND ACCORDING TO SPECIFICATIONS,BUT TARGETS HAVE NOT BEEN MET. MASTER PLANNING FOR PHASE II HAS BEEN OVERSHADOWED BY THE HEAVY PRESSURES ON HAVA AND THE SOIL CONSERVATION SERVICE TO DEMONSTRATE PROGRESS ON PHYSICAL CONSTRUCTION. THE EVALUATORS MAKE SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT USAID PROJECT MANAGEMENT, HAVA PROJECT MANAGEMENT, DESIGN PRODUCTION, FIELD DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS, FARM DRAIN CONSTRUCTION, MAIN DRAIN CONSTRUCTION, AND PLANNING FOR PHASE II. THEIR PRIMARY CONCLUSION IS THAT THERE IS INSUFFICIENT BASIS TO RECOMMEND A GO-AHEAD DECISION ON PHASE II UNITL THERE IS CLEAR EVIDENCE THAT EXPANDED PHYSICAL OUTPUT IS LIKELY AND PLANNING HAS CLEARLY DELINEATED IMPLEMENTABLE PROJECT CONTENT.

Abstract: THE PLANNED MALARIA ACTIVITIES OF THE NATIONAL MALARIA ERADICATION ORGANIZATION (NMEO) MEET OVERALL NATIONAL OBJECTIVES BY: (1)INCREASING IMPROVED WORKING CONDITIONS FOR AGRICULTURE DEVELOPMENT IN FORMELY MALARIOUS AREAS; (2) MAINTAINING A HEALTHY WORK FORCE TO PRODUCE CROPS AND MATERIALS REQUIRED BY THE NATION; AND (3)ALLOWING THE MALARIOUS REGIONS OF THE COUNTRY TO TAKE THEIR RIGHTFUL PLACE IN THE REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT SCHEMES OF THE COUNTRY. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE MALARIA ERADICATION BOARD AND THE NMEO ARE FOCUSED ON THE CONTROL OF MALARIA TO A LEVEL WHERE IT IS NO LONGER A PUBLIC HEALTH PROBLEM AND TO FACILITATE THE ORDERLY DEVELOPMENT OF BASIC HEALTH SERVICES IN NEPAL. THE EVALUATORS DISCUSS: (1)CURRENT EPIDEMIOLOGICAL STATUS OF MALARIA IN NEPAL; (2)MANAGERIAL METHODS AND PROBLEMS IN THE NATIONAL AND REGIONAL OFFICES; (3)OPERATIONAL ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND PROBLEMS IN 1975; AND (4)INTEGRATED ACTIVITIES OF THE NMEO INTO THE HEALTH SERVICES. THEY ALSO REVIEW NMEO ACTIVITIES AND EMPHASIZE THAT PROPER, PLANNED, AND ADEQUATE SUPPORT SHOULD BE GIVEN TO THE NMEO SO IT CAN MEET ITS RESPONSIBILITY IN THE ATTAINMENT OF NATIONAL OBJECTIVES. THEY MAKE A TOTAL OF 49 RECOMMENDATIONS ON ADMINISTRATIVE, OPERATIONAL, AND TECHNICAL MATTERS.

Abstract: THE TEAM RECOMMENDS THAT THE AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH LOAN PROJECT BE CONTINUED WITHOUT MODIFICATION FOR ONE ADDITIONAL YEAR. THE TEAM CONCLUDES THAT ALTHOUGH THE PROGRAM OF WORK IS TOO AMBITIOUS, THE PROJECT IS SOUNDLY CONCEIVED AND CONSISTENT WITH CURRENT AND LONG-RANGE NATIONAL GOALS FOR STRENGTHENING RESEARCH CAPABILITY FOR OVERALL IMPROVEMENT IN THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR. PROBLEMS ARE: (1)CHANGES IN PERSONNEL AND LOCATION OF STAFF PLUS THE ABSENCE OF A REGULARLY APPOINTED DIRECTOR GENERAL SEEM TO HAVE SERIOUSLY RESTRICTED PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION; (2) IMPLEMENTATION OF TRAINING, COMMODITY PROCUREMENT, AND LOGISTIC SUPPORT WAS INADEQUATE; AND (3)BECAUSE OF PROBLEMS REGARDING ACQUISITION OF LAND FOR THE PAKISTAN AGRICULTUAL RESEARCH CENTER (PARC), NO CONSTRUCTION HAS BEGUN. DESPITE PROBLEMS ENCOUNTERED, HOWEVER, THE AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH COUNCIL (ARC) IS TO BE COMMENDED FOR MOVING AHEAD IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NATIONAL RESEARCH PROGRAM. THE EVALUATORS MADE SEVERAL SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS REGARDING: (1)ADMINISTRATION OF ARC; (2)TRAINING; (3)COMMODITY PROCUREMENT; (4)TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE; (5)ARC BUILDING AND HOUSING; (6)PARC; (7)NATIONAL ADMINISTRATION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF RESEARCH; (8)RESEARCH IN AGRICULTRAL DEPARTMENTS IN THE PROVINCES; AND (9) RESEARCH IN AGRICULTURAL COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES.

Abstract: THE MAIN TARGET OF THE MISAMIS ORIENTAL RURAL ELECTRIC SERVICE COOPERATIVE (MORESCO) HAS BEEN THE MAJORITY OF THE PEOPLE WHO ARE POOR IN TERMS OF ECONOMIC GOODS. THE TARGET GROUP HAS SUBSTANTIALLY BENEFITTED FROM THE PROJECT BY INCREASED QUALITY IN SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC LIFE. IN ADDITION, OTHER SEGMENTS OF SOCIETY HAVE SHARED IN THE PROJECT'S BENEFITS. ELECTRIFICATION HAS IMPROVED HEALTH STANDARDS THROUGH (1)PURE AND SAFE WATER, (2)GREATER AVAILABILITY OF SERVICES PROVIDED BY CLINICS AND HOSPITALS, AND (3)GREATER USE OF REFRIGERATORS TO COMBAT FOOD SPOILAGE. ELECTRIFICATION HAS INCREASED THE USE AND EFFECTIVENESS OF EXISTING EDUCATIONAL FACILITIES. IT HAS MADE HOMES SAFER AND RAISED THE QUALITY OF LIFE BY INTRODUCING HOUSEHOLD APPLIANCES SUCH AS ELECTRIC IRONS. PRODUCTION HAS INCREASED IN EXISTING BUSINESSES AND INDUSTRIES, AND NEW BUSINESSES HAVE BEEN ATTRACTED TO THE AREA BECAUSE OF THE CHEAP ELECTRICITY. AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION HAS INCREASED DUE TO BOTH WATER AND LIGHTING (HOGS, POULTRY, ETC.) EMPLOYMENT AND INCOME HAVE INCREASED BECAUSE OF THE GREATER NUMBER OF BETTER-PAYING JOBS IN THE AREA DUE TO THE GROWING DEVELOPMENT OF BUSINESSES, AND DUE TO THE GREATER PRODUCTIVITY OF FARMS BASED UPON ELECTRICITY.

Abstract: THE OBJECTIVE OF THE SPECIAL STUDIES UNIT (SSU) IS TO BE SUPPORTIVE THROUGH ITS ANALYTICAL WORK OF THE INTEGRATION EFFORTS IN CENTRAL AMERICA. THE MAJOR INSTRUMENT USED TO ACCOMPLISH THIS IS THE UNDERTAKING OF A NUMBER OF STUDIES BY THE STAFF OF THE SSU. THE PROJECT HAS ACCOMPLISHED ITS OBJECTIVE OF PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN PLANNING AND EXECUTING THE STUDIES. AN INSTITUTIONAL RESEARCH AND ANALYTICAL CAPACITY HAS BEEN ADDED TO SIECA WHICH DID NOT EXIST BEFORE THE PROJECT. THERE IS SOME FEELING THAT THE SSU'S WORK, IN SOME RESPECTS, IS TOO THEORETICAL TO BE OF DIRECT RELEVANCE TO THE INTEGRATION PROCESS. SINCE MOST OF THE STUDIES WERE ONLY RECENTLY COMPLETED IN THEIR FINAL FORM, LITTLE HAS BEEN ACCOMPLISHED IN MAKING THE FINDINGS AVAILABLE TO THOSE INFLUENTIAL AND CONCERNED WITH THE INTEGRATION PROCESS. IT IS QUITE CLEAR THAT A LARGE EFFORT NEEDS TO BE MOUNTED IN ORDER TO DISSEMINATE THE FINDINGS AND PROMOTE THEIR UTILIZATION BY THE PROPER PEOPLE AND INSTITUTIONS. THE MAJOR TASK FOR THE SSU SHOULD BE CARRY OUT ANALYSIS WHICH POINTS TO THE PARTICULAR PROBLEMS THAT NEED TO BE ADDRESSED IN A COLLABORATIVE FASHION AND THE CONSTRAINTS THAT MUST BE OVERCOME BEFORE EFFECTIVE ACTION CAN BE TAKEN. AN EFFORT TO RETAIN BROOKINGS SHOULD BE MADE ON THE CONDITION THAT CHANGES IN FUNDINGS AND TIMING OF RESIDENCE IN CENTRAL AMERICA ARE MADE.

Abstract: THE PROGRAM OF THE PARTNERS SERVES THE INTEREST OF THE UNITED STATES BY INVOLVING VOLUNTEERS IN ACTIVITIES TO BUILD BRIDGES BETWEEN THE PEOPLE OF THE UNITED STATES AND THE PEOPLE OF LATIN AMERICA AND TO PROVIDE INEXPENSIVE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND TRAINING THAT CONTRIBUTES TO DEVELOPMENT. HOWEVER, WITH ONLY 30 TO 200 MEMBERS IN EACH OF THE STATE PARTNERS VISITED, THE PROGRAM IS FAR FROM ITS POTENTIAL. THE EVALUATION WAS HANDICAPPED BY LACK OF RELIABLE STATISTICAL INFORMATION, BUT A STUDY OF 46 PROJECTS SHOWED A SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION TO DEVELOPMENT AT A VERY LOW COST TO THE UNITED STATES. DESPITE THE SMALL SIZE OF THEIR ACTIVE MEMBERSHIP, THE STATE PARTNERS ARE REASONABLY EFFECTIVE IN OBTAINING THE PARTICIPATION OF THE PRIVATE AND PUBLIC SECTOR IN COLLABORATIVE ACTIVITIES WITH THEIR LATIN AMERICAN PARTNERS AND IN STIMULATING PUBLIC AWARENESS. THE LATIN AMERICAN PARTNERS, WITH EVEN MORE LIMITED MEMBERSHIP THAN THEIR US PARTNERS, ARE GENERALLY EFFECTIVE IN DRAWING ON THE PRIVATE SECTOR AND SOME GOVERNMENTAL RESOURCES FOR MODEST BUT EFFECTIVE PROJECTS WHICH BENEFIT THEIR COUNTRIES. ALL NEED GUIDANCE ON PARTNER OPERATIONS, PROGRAM AND PROJECT DEVELOPMENT, AND DEVELOPMENT PRIORITIES. THE EVALUATORS MADE MANY RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDING: (1)STATE PARTNERS SHOULD EXPAND THEIR PROGRAMS AND THEIR MEMBERSHIP; AND (2)AID AND THE PARTNERS SHOULD PLAN ON AN ORDERLY PHASE-OUT OF AID FINANCING.

Abstract: BASED ON NATIONAL FIGURES AND EVALUATORS' OBSERVATIONS, IT IS EVIDENT THAT IN TEN YEARS, THE MOROCCAN NATIONAL FAMILY PLANNING PROGRAM HAD ALMOST NO DEMOGRAPHIC EFFECT. ANY MODEST FALL IN THE BIRTH RATE IS MORE THE RESULT OF SOCIAL CHANGE THAN THE EXTENSION OF FAMILY PLANNING. THERE HAS BEEN SLIGHT PROGRESS; HOWEVER, THE BASIC FIGURES ARE SO LOW THAT IT IS MORE APPARENT THAN REAL. IN ADDITION, THE DROP-OUT RATE IN HIGH. ON THE POSITIVE SIDE, THERE IS POTENTIAL WITHIN THE IMPRESSIVE NATIONAL PUBLIC HEALTH INFRASTRUCTURE FOR AN EFFECTIVE FAMILY PLANNING PROGRAM. THE PRINCIPAL PROBLEMS ARE: (1)A LACK OF PRIORITY EMPHASIS, (2)AN ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURE WHICH FORESTALLS THE POSSIBILITY OF EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT, AND (3)INSUFFICIENT INFORMATION, EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS, AND TRAINING. THE PRINCIPAL RECOMMENDATIONS ARE: (1)THAT THE GOVERNMENT OF MOROCCO (GOM) ASSIGN A HIGH PRIORITY TO FAMILY PLANNING WITHIN ITS INTEGRATED HEALTH DELIVERY SYSTEM; AND (2)THAT ONLY IF THE GOM ACTS QUICKLY TO INCREASE THE EMPHASIS ON FAMILY PLANNING SHOULD AID ASSIGN A HIGH PRIORITY TO THE REAL NEEDS OF THE PROGRAM. THE EVALUATORS MAKE A TOTAL OF 45 RECOMMENDATIONS ON SUCH THINGS AS MANAGEMENT, NEW METHODS OF DISTRIBUTION, INFORMATION AND EDUCATION, STATUS OF WOMEN, SERVICE DELIVERY, REFERENCE CENTERS, STERILIZATION, AND REDUCTION OF ILLEGAL ABORTIONS.

Abstract: THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT WAS TO ACHIEVE A HIGH LEVEL OF NET OFFTAKE IN THE MASAI DISTRICT. TO DATE LITTLE HAS BEEN ACCOMPLISHED WITH RESPECT TO ATTAINING THE CONDITION EXPECTED AT THE END OF THE PROJECT. THERE IS LITTLE EVIDENCE THAT PRODUCTION INDICES SUCH AS INCREASED CALF DROPS, LARGER ANIMALS, YOUNGER ANIMALS BEING MARKETED, AND INCREASED NET OFFTAKE HAVE MATERIALIZED. THIS SHORTFALL IS DUE TO SLOWER THAN ANTICIPATED PROGRESS IN PHYSICAL DEVELOPMENT, IMPLEMENTATION OF IMPROVED GRAZING PRACTICES, AND LAG IN THE CATTLE IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM. THE ASSUMPTIONS RESPECTING ACHIEVEMENT OF PROJECT PURPOSES HAVE NOT BEEN BORNE OUT. PROGRESS IS BEING MADE WITH RESPECT TO ANIMAL HEALTH AND DISEASE CONTROL, BUT THERE HAS BEEN NO EVIDENT CHANGE IN MASAI ATTITUDES ABOUT DEVELOPMENT OF A MARKET ORIENTATION. THE EVALUATORS MADE 21 RECOMMENDATIONS, INCLUDING: (1)THE CONTRACTOR FOR THE MASAI TEAM SHOULD BE CHANGED; (2)THE TRAINING PROGRAM SHOULD BE ACCELERATED; (3)THE PARTICIPANT TRAINING PROGRAM SHOULD BE MODIFIED; (4)THE RANGE MANAGEMENT CAPABILITY SHOULD BE EXPANDED TO BRING IT INTO BALANCE WITH THAT OF THE WATER COMPONENT; (5)THE SOCIOLOGICAL INPUTS SHOULD BE REDIRECTED TO PROVIDE A MEANS OF MONITORING PROGRESS AND CHANGE AMONG THE MASAI; AND (6)THE HYDROGEOLOGIST SHOULD GIVE PRIORITY TO IDENTIFYING PROMISING BOREHOLE SITES.

Abstract: THE EVALUATORS DISCUSS THEIR SCOPE OF WORK AND METHODOLOGY AND REVIEW: (1)THE RESEARCH STRATEGY, METHODS, INPUTS, AND OUTPUTS; (2)THE RESEARCH PROGRAM, MANPOWER RESOURCES AND DEVELOPMENT, AND ADMINISTRATION; AND (3)THE SECTOR GOAL AND PROJECT PURPOSE. AFTER CONSIDERABLE DELAY, THE PROJECT WAS STARTED UP IN 1973, SHORT OF PROGRAMMED INPUTS BUT WITH A SCIENTIFICALLY SOUND APPROACH. DUE TO THE ASTUTENESS AND GOOD FORTUNE OF THE SCIENTISTS, THE PROJECT HAS PRODUCED HIGHLY SIGNIFICANT OUTPUTS IN ITS FIRST TWO YEARS OF OPERATION. THE PROJECT IS PROGRESSING WELL IN SPITE OF THE FACT THAT THE PROJECT STAFF PROVIDED FOR IN THE BASIC PROJECT AGREEMENT IS 80 PERCENT COMPLETE. RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDE: (1)DRAFT A STATEMENT OF GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH SERVICE; (2)DEVISE A SYSTEM OF PLANNING, BUDGETING AND IMPLEMENTATION THAT HARMONIZES WITH NATIONAL CROP DEVELOPMENT PURPOSES, INPUTS AND PROCEDURES, AND THOSE OF THE REGIONAL RESEARCH INSTITUTES; (3)PLACE MORE EMPHASIS ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF MANPOWER FOR THE RESEARCH PROGRAM; (4)PLACE MORE EMPHASIS ON INFORMAL, ON-THE-JOB TRAINING OF RESEARCH COLLEAGUES; (5)CONTINUE THE DEVELOPMENT OF HIGH LYSINE MAIZE AND SHORT-SEASON MAIZE; AND (6)INCLUDE SORGHUM AND MILLET RESEARCH IN THE PROJECT

Abstract: EVALUATES ENTENTE AFRICAN ENTERPRISES LOAN. THE LOAN WAS RAPIDLY AND WELL-DISBURSED DUE PRIMARILY TO ITS FLEXIBILITY AT THE LEVEL OF THE DEVELOPMENT BANK WHICH ENABLED THE BANK TO USE THIS MONEY WHERE OTHER CREDIT SOURCES WERE EXCLUDED. A HIGH PERCENTAGE OF THE LOAN WAS USED FOR WORKING CAPITAL, REFLECTING ONE OF THE GREAT NEEDS OF AFRICAN ENTERPRISES AND SUGGESTING THAT THE COMMERCIAL BANK SYSTEM BE INDUCED TO PROVIDE THIS CREDIT. HOWEVER, FEW GUIDELINES WERE ATTACHED TO THE LOAN, AND A LEARNING EXPERIENCE DEVELOPED WHICH THE ENTENTE FUND FAILED TO GENERALIZE ACROSS COUNTRIES. ABUSE OCCURRED DUE TO SELECTIVE ACCESS TO CHEAP CREDIT, WHICH SOME BANKS CHOSE NEITHER TO PASS ON LOWER INTEREST RATES TO THE ENTREPRENEUR, NOR TO PROVIDE EXTRA SERVICES EXPECTED OF THEM UNDER THE LOAN. IN ADDITION, DOLLAR PROCUREMENT WAS ABUSED, IN THAT LITTLE EQUIPMENT WAS ACQUIRED,SPECIFICALLY BECAUSE OF THE LOAN,WHILE TAX-FREE STATUS SPECIFIED IN THE LOAN AGREEMENT LED TO UNNECESSARY ABUSE. THE FOLLOWING RECOMMENDATIONS WERE MADE: 1)THE DEFINITION OF AFRICAN ENTERPRISE MUST BE MADE MORE RIGOROUS; 2)THE LOAN SHOULD BE GUIDED MORE TO SMALL AND MEDIUM ENTERPRISES; 3)GREATER USE SHOULD BE MADE OF THE RESOURCES; 4)BANKS SHOULD BE REQUIRED TO HIRE BANKING PERSONNEL USING INCOME FROM THE LOAN; 5)THE EXPERIMENTAL CHARACTER OF THE LOAN SHOULD BE MAINTAINED BY KEEPING GUIDELINES AS LOOSE AS POSSIBLE; 6) NO REQUIREMENT SHOULD BE MADE TO LOAN IN SPECIAL SECTORS; 7)PARTICIPATION IN FIRMS SHOULD BE CIRCUMSCRIBED TO PREVENT ABUSE IN TERMS OF APPROPRIATION OF EXPATRIATE ENTERPRISES; 8)SATEC ASSISTANCE MUST BE CONTINUED FOR THE NEXT YEAR; 9)THE REQUIREMENT FOR CODE 941 PROCUREMENT MUST BE ABOLISHED DUE TO DIFFICULTIES AND ABUSES; 10)ON CODE 941 PROCUREMENT, THE WORDING OF THE LOAN MUST BE CHANGED TO PERMIT THE ENTREPRENEUR TO PAY DUTIES AND TAXES; 11)CODE 935 PROCUREMENT REQUIREMENT ON NON-LOAN ASPECTS SHOULD BE ABOLISHED AND; 12)SPECIAL ACCOUNTS KEPT BY THE ENTENTE FUND TO REPAY THE LOAN SHOULD BE AUTHORIZED.

Title: EVALUATION REPORT : ENTENTE AFRICAN ENTERPRISES LOAN, 625-H-006; ENTENTE AFRICAN ENTERPRISES PROJECT, 625-15-920-717

Abstract: Evaluates project performance from 1973 to 1978 in Botswana. Purpose of project is to assist the Government of Botswana (GOB) to develop socially acceptable range and livestock production/management models. Evaluation methodology based on interviews and onsite observations. Project has enjoyed little success.  Underestimation of the importance of sociological surveys and staff to conduct them have been the greatest reason for failure.  In each of three communities chosen to benefit by the project all or some of the following situations exist: 1. conflict between farmers and herders as to who may benefit from the project; 2. disputes between neighboring villages as to the grazing rights and boundaries; 3. lack of communication since communities chosen are minority groups speaking minor languages & having been little studied as to their origin, customs, etc; 4. lack of help from government officials who were unsure as to what their responsibilities were; and 5. lack of a sense of directn and skills among personnel. Other minor problems have been poor grass species for fodder production, equipment shortages, inadequate living conditions for staff at the beginning of the project, and delays in vehicle repairs.  It is believed that project may not be economically feasible even with the two year extension being suggested. Recommendations are to:  1. improve interaction between AID and the Botswana communities served by utilizing Peace Corps type volunteers, junior officers, and team members; 2. add a rural sociologist to the team; 3. place team in a coordinate position in the Department of Agriculture; 4. agree upon policies and guidelines governing the organization of communal groups; 5. provide better servicing of equipment; 6. study the economics; 7. find other forms of training for personnel; and 8. perform an early evaluation of the next program.

Abstract: THE DENTAL HEALTH INTERNATIONAL (DHI) PROJECT HAS CREATED CONSIDERABLE POLITICAL AND GENERAL PUBLIC FAVOR. IT HAS NOT MADE SUBSTANTIVE CHANGES IN ORAL HEALTH, NOR WOULD SUCH A BRIEF EFFORT BE EXPECTED TO HAVE SUCH AN IMPACT. UNIFORM SUPPORT FOR THE CONCEPT INDICATES THAT PROGRAM MODIFICATIONS COULD LEAD TO LONG TERM EFFECTIVE RESULTS. THE CURRENT REQUIREMENT THAT THE PROJECT BE ECONOMICALLY SELF-SUFFICIENT HANDICAPS ACHIEVEMENT OF OBJECTIVES IN PREVENTION AND EDUCATION AND IN REACHING THE GREATEST POSSIBLE RURAL POPULATION. IT IS BETTER SUITED AS A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT TO DEFINE ORAL HEALTH NEEDS, TO DETERMINE METHODS FOR DENTAL SERVICE DELIVERY AND TO ELEVATE PUBLIC RECOGNITION OF ORAL HEALTH AS A LEGITIMATE SOCIAL CONCERN. THE OPPORTUNITY PRESENTED BY THE PROJECT TO COLLECT DATA THAT WILL BE ESSENTIAL TO RATIONAL DENTAL PROBLEM DEFINITION AND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT HAS SO FAR BEEN OVERLOOKED. THE DHI GRANT SHOULD BE CONTINUED BECAUSE IT: (1)IS AN EXCELLENT DEMONSTRATION PROJECT; (2)HAS THE POTENTIAL TO PROVIDE IMPORTANT DATA; AND (3)IS RESPECTED AND APPRECIATED BY THE GOVERNMENTS WHO ARE UNABLE TO CARRY ON AN ORAL HEALTH PROGRAM WITH NATIONAL RESOURCES. THE EVALUATOR DISCUSSES (1)DHI AND LOCAL HOSPITAL ADMINISTRATION, (2)DHI AND LOCAL HOSPITAL TRAINING, (3)USAID AND DHI RELATIONS, (4)TARGET GROUP RESPONSE AND PROJECT GOALS AND PURPOSES, AND (5)THE PROBLEM OF AN ADEQUATE POWER SUPPLY.

Abstract: THIS REPORT DESCRIBES THE RESULTS OF APPLYING EVALUATION TECHNIQUES IN THE "FIELD GUIDE FOR EVALUATION OF NUTRITION EDUCATION: AN EXPERIMENTAL APPROACH TO DETERMINATION OF EFFECTS ON FOOD BEHAVIOR IN LESSER DEVELOPED COUNTRIES". THIS GUIDE WAS DEVELOPED BECAUSE AID CONCLUDED THAT AN EFFECTIVE MEANS FOR DETERMINING THE COST-EFFECTIVENESS OF EDUCATION AS IT RELATES TO FOOD BEHAVIOR WAS NECESSARY. THE GUIDE WAS FIELD-TESTED ON THREE PROGRAMS IN BRAZIL, ONE FOCUSING ON CLASSROOM EDUCATION, ONE USING A NONFORMAL EDUCATION APPROACH, AND ONE USING THE MASS MEDIA. THE REPORT DISCUSSES THE BASIC REQUIREMENTS FOR THE METHODOLOGY AND THE KEY ISSUES IN THE FIELD DEMONSTRATION: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN; WHICH FOOD BEHAVIORS SHOULD BE MEASURED; QUANTIFICATION BY FREQUENCY VERSUS AMOUNT; CATEGORIZED VERSUS CONTINUOUS DATA CONCEPTS; AND GENERALIZABILITY TO MULTIPLE PROGRAM LEVELS. FIVE RECOMMENDATIONS DERIVED FROM THE DEVELOPMENTAL WORK, CONFERENCES WITH THE PANEL OF EXPERTS, AND EXPERIENCES IN THE FIELD DEMONSTRATION: (1)FURTHER FIELD APPLICATIONS SHOULD BE CARRIED OUT TO ENSURE THE UTILITY OF THE METHODOLOGY FOR COST-EFFECTIVENESS COMPARISONS; (2)AN OBJECTIVE OF FURTHER APPLICATIONS OF THE METHODOLOGY SHOULD BE THE DETERMINATION OF NEED FOR ALTERNATIVE AND LESS SOPHISTICATED METHODS, AND EXPLORATION OF POSSIBLE TECHNIQUES; (3)CONSIDERATION SHOULD BE GIVEN TO DEVELOPMENT OF SUPPLEMENTS TO THE FIELD GUIDE TO PROVIDE PROCEDURAL MODELS FOR MEASURES OF ADDITIONAL FOOD BEHAVIORS SUCH AS FOOD ACQUISITION, STORAGE, AND PREPARATION; (4)CONSIDERATION SHOULD BE GIVEN TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SUMMARY HANDBOOK FOR PROGRAM ADMINISTRATORS AND PLANNERS; AND (5)AID SHOULD PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO GOVERNMENTS AND TO VOLUNTARY AND INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS WHICH MAY REQUEST SUCH HELP IN EVALUATION OF THEIR NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMS. THE REPORT CONTAINS ANALYSES OF THE RESULTS OF THE THREE DEMONSTRATIONS IN BRAZIL.

Abstract: DURING PROGRAM YEAR IV, THIS PROJECT, DESIGNED TO PROVIDE TRAINING AND STUDY PROGRAMS IN FAMILY PLANNING, DEMOGRAPHY, POPULATION STUDIES, AND RELATED FIELDS IN THE WESTERN HEMISPHERE TO LATIN AMERICAN AND CARIBBEAN GRANTEES, TRAINED MORE PARTICIPANTS AND PROVIDED MORE PERSON/WEEKS OF TRAINING THAN IN ANY PRECEDING PROGRAM YEAR. Abstract: THE EVALUATORS DISCUSSED THE OBJECTIVES OF THE WORLD FERTILITY SURVEY (WFS), THE DIFFERENCES IN OBJECTIVES, INTERNATIONAL COMPARABILITY OF THE DATA GATHERED, RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF NATIONAL CAPACITIES. AS THE WFS PROJECT CONTINUES TO GROW IN COMPLEXITY, IT IS INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT THAT THE VARIOUS OBJECTIVES BE RANKED ACCORDING TO PRIORITY AND THAT THE FUTURE WORK PLANS RELFECT THIS RANKING. THE WFS WILL ACHIEVE QUITE GOOD COVERAGE, ASSUMING THAT INDIA AND MUCH OF AFRICA WILL BE INCLUDED. THERE ARE SIGNIFICANT OMISSIONS, BUT IT APPEARS AS IF THE INITIAL GOALS OF COUNTRY PARTICIPATION WILL BE MET. WITH NECESSARY CONSTRAINTS ON THE SIZE OF THE QUESTIONNAIRE, THE CONTENT OF THE QUESTIONNAIRES DOES INCLUDE THE MAJOR FACTORS AFFECTING FERTILITY. THE WFS HAS ALSO BEEN ABLE TO RESIST THE TEMPTATION TO ATTACH OTHER ITEMS,OF INTEREST FOR SOCIAL RESEARCH BUT SEEN AS HAVING ONLY MARGINAL EFFECT ON FERTILITY ANALYSIS. THE WSF HAS PLACED CONSIDERABLE EMPHASIS ON THE PRODUCTION OF HIGH-QUALITY SURVEYS. THE WFS STAFF IS AWARE OF THE LIMITATIONS OF SURVEY DATA, AND PLANS ARE UNDERWAY FOR AN EARLY ANALYSIS OF THE QUALITY OF THE DATA. FROM THE POINT OF VIEW OF DEMOGRAPHY AND DEMOGRAPHIC ANALYSIS, THE WFS IS MAKING TWO MAJOR CONTRIBUTIONS: (1)THE DATA THAT ARE BEING PRODUCED WILL ADD SUBSTANTIALLY TO THE BODY OF KNOWLEDGE ABOUT FERTILITY PATTERNS; AND (2)THE WFS IS HELPING COORDINATE AND CENTRALIZE ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON FERTILITY THROUGHOUT THE WORLD. PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION WAS INITIALLY FORESEEN TO LAST THREE YEARS. IT NOW SEEMS UNLIKELY THAT THIS SCHEDULE CAN BE ADHERED TO, AND THE INTERNATIONAL STATISTICS INSTITUTE HAS SUGGESTED AN EXTENSION OF THE WFS TO MID-1982. THE EVALUATORS RECOMMENDED THAT THIS EXTENSION BE GRANTED AND THEY MADE RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT WAYS IN WHICH THE PRIORITIES OF WFS OBJECTIVES SHOULD BE RECONSIDERED IF WFS WILL BE GIVEN A FIVE-YEAR EXTENSION.

Abstract: AIRLIE FOUNDATION HAS PRODUCED APPROXIMATELY 100 FILMS ON FAMILY PLANNING AND RELATED TOPICS FOR LATIN AMERICAN AND WORLDWIDE AUDIENCES. MOST OF THESE FILMS ARE GENERAL INFORMATIONAL AND MOTIVATIONAL FILMS, BUT A NUMBER ARE TECHNICAL AND FOR PROFESSIONAL AUDIENCES. THE MAJOR FINDING WAS THAT THE AIRLIE-PRODUCED FILMS ARE OF SUFFICIENT QUALITY TO FULFILL AIRLIE'S CONTRACTUAL OBLIGATIONS. THEY EXCELLED IN TECHNICAL QUALITY BUT DREW VARYING COMMENTS ON THEIR CONTENT. IN GENERAL TERMS, THE MORE SOPHISTICATED THE AUDIENCE, THE MORE CRITICAL THE COMMENTS, LESS SOPHISTICATED PERSONS WERE ALMOST ALWAYS FAVORABLY IMPRESSED, AND MANY FAMILY PLANNING AGENCY STAFF MEMBERS FELT THE FILMS WERE BEST USED FOR GENERAL AUDIENCES IN CONJUNCTION WITH MOTIVATIONAL AND EDCUATIONAL MEETINGS. BECAUSE LESS SOPHISTICATED AUDIENCES APPEAR TO BE MORE SUSCEPTIBLE TO INFORMATION CONTAINED IN FILMS, IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT THIS INFORMATION BE COMPREHENSIVE AND ACCURATE. ANOTHER MAJOR FINDING WAS THAT THE DISTRIBUTION AND UTILIZATION OF THE FILMS HAVE NOT BEEN WELL CONCEIVED OR COORDINATED. THERE IS A CONTINUING NEED FOR SPANISH-LANGUAGE FAMILY PLANNING FILMS PRODUCED IN LATIN AMERICA AND DIRECTED TOWARD LATIN AMERICAN AUDIENCES. PEOPLE NOW SAY THEY WANT SPECIFIC INFORMATION ON BIRTH CONTROL METHODS AND RELATED FAMILY PLANNING SUBJECTS. MOTIVATION IS NOT AS RELEVANT AS IT WAS IN 1971, WHEN THE ORIGINAL CONTRACT WAS WRITTEN. AND ALTHOUGH THE COUNTRY-SPECIFIC FILMS ARE GENERALLY LIKED BETTER THAT THE REGIONAL FILMS, THE EVALUATORS BELIEVE THAT IT WOULD BE MORE COST-EFFECTIVE TO PRODUCE REGIONAL FILMS, ESPECIALLY FOR TECHNICAL AND SEMI-TECHNICAL SUBJECTS. IT WOULD APPEAR THAT THE ABILITY OF A GIVEN FILM TO EFFECTIVELY COMMUNICATE ITS SUBJECT MATTER WOULD BE SIGNIFICANTLY ENHANCED BY A MORE RESTRICTED DEFINITION OF THE INTENDED TARGET AUDIENCE. THE EVALUATORS MADE 2L RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT PLANNING, PRODUCTION, DISTRIBUTION, AND EVALUATION.

Abstract: IN GENERAL, THE EVALUATORS VIEWED WITH SATISFACTION THE ACCOMPLISHMENTS OF THE PROGRAM OF INTERNATIONAL TRAINING AND RESEARCH IN FAMILY PLANNING INFORMATION, EDUCATION AND COMMUNICATION OF THE COMMUNITY AND FAMILY STUDY CENTER (CGSC) OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO. AFTER FIVE YEARS OF OPERATION, THE PROGRAM APPEARS TO HAVE ACCOMPLISHED MOST OF THE TASKS IT ORIGINALLY SET OUT TO DO. THE CFSC HAD 7 FUNCTIONAL GOALS CONCERNING: (1)GRADUATE DEGREE PROGRAMS; (2)SUMMER WORKSHOPS; (3)NON-DEGREE SHORT-TERM PROGRAMS; (4)PUBLICATIONS AND MATERIALS; (5)A COMMUNICATION WITH FAMILY PLANNING PROGRAMS IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; (6)SPECIAL SEMINARS; AND (7)A COMMUNICATION LABORATORY. ALTHOUGH THE NUMBER OF GRADUATES IN THE GRADUATE PROGRAM IS LESS THAN PLANNED, VIRTUALLY ALL HAVE RETURNED TO POPULATION-RELATED WORK IN THEIR HOME COUNTRIES. SUMMER WORKSHOPS ARE THE OLDEST FACET OF THE CFSC PROGRAM. THEY HAVE SERVED MORE THAN 1100 PARTICIPANTS SINCE 1963 FROM 80 COUNTRIES AND HAVE GAINED A STRONG REPUTATION AMONG FAMILY PLANNING PROFESSIONALS AROUND THE WORLD. THE SEMINARS AND WORKSHOPS HAVE BEEN VALUABLE IN BRINGING TOGETHER MEDIA SPECIALISTS AND OFFICIALS WORKING IN THE FAMILY PLANNING PROGRAMS AND MAKING THEM AWARE OF THE NEED FOR GREATER COLLABORATION. THE GENERAL REACTION TO THE PUBLICATIONS WAS THAT THEY WERE USEFUL IN GIVING BROAD GUIDELINES FOR DECISION AND ACTION. THE EVALUATORS ENCOURAGED CFSC TO CONTINUE ITS PRACTICE OF CONDUCTING RESEARCH AS A TOOL FOR DECISION-MAKING AND NOT SIMPLY FOR ITS OWN SAKE. THE SPECIAL CONFERENCES AND SEMINARS ARE A MOST IMPORTANT ASPECT FOR CONTINUOUS REVITALIZATION OF THE PROGRAM. Abstract: THE MOST SIGNIFICANT SHORTCOMING OF THE PROGRAM AT THIS TIME IS THE LACK OF AN EFFECTIVE STRATEGY AND ACTION PLAN GEARED TO CREATING CONSUMER DEMAND. IF THE PROGRAM IS TO SUCCEED, A COMMERCIAL DEMAND CREATION, MARKETING, AND CONTRACEPTIVE DISTRIBUTION PROGRAM MUST BE DEVELOPED, TESTED, AND IMPLEMENTED WITH DELIBERATE SPEED. DEMAND FOR BIRTH CONTROL SERVICES HAS STABILIZED AT A VERY LOW LEVEL. CONTRACEPTIVE ACCEPTANCE RATES ARE THE SAME AS THEY WERE IN 1968. ALL AVAILABLE WAREHOUSE SPACE AND ALL DISTRIBUTION CHANNELS ARE FILLED TO CAPACITY. MORE OUTLETS AT THE RETAIL LEVEL ARE NEEDED TO ABSORB THIS SUPPLY. PRESENT MARKETING EFFORTS IN SUPPORT OF THE INUNDATION PROGRAM ARE DEVOID OF STRATEGY, IMPROPERLY UTILIZE THE MEDIA CHANNELS, LACK APPROPRIATE POINT OF SALES MATERIALS, AND DO NOT STIMULATE CONSUMER DEMAND. THERE IS PRESENTLY UNDERWAY A HIGHLY EFFECTIVE STUDY OF COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION OF CONTRACEPTIVES THROUGH THE COMMERCIAL SECTOR, EMPLOYING SUCH FAMILIAR TACTICS AS ATTITUDINAL ASSESSMENT, PACKAGING, AND MARKETING TECHNIQUES DESIGNED TO GET SHOPKEEPERS TO BECOME SALES AGENTS. THE EVALUATOR DISCUSSED CURRENT CONSUMER ATTITUDES, THE COMMERCIAL DELIVERY SYSTEM, AND NEW PROGRAM MANAGEMENT NEEDS. HE MADE ELEVEN RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDING THAT: (1)A PUBLIC OPINION RESEARCH PROJECT BE UNDERTAKEN; (2)A COMMERCIALLY-RUN CONTRACEPTIVE DISTRIBUTION AND MARKETING SYSTEM BE TESTED, MODIFIED AND IMPLEMENTED; AND (3)THE FAMILY PLANNING EFFORT BE NATIONALIZED.

Abstract: THE HAITIAN AMERICAN COMMUNITY HELP ORGANIZATION (HACHO) HAS THREE MAJOR FUNCTIONAL AREAS; MEDICAL; COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT; AND AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT. A SURVEY INDICATES THAT ALMOST 80 PERCENT OF AREA RESIDENTS HAVE RECEIVED IMPORTANT BENEFITS FROM PROJECTS UNDERTAKEN BY THE HACHO SERVICES. HACHO DEVOTES MORE RESOURCES TO THE MEDICAL SERVICE THAN TO ANY OTHER. WHILE THE AREA HAS BENEFITED GREATLY FROM THESE SERVICES, THEY COULD BE MADE MORE EFFICIENT. THE MEDICAL FACILIITES, THE OUTPATIENT FACILITIES, THE INPATIENT HOSPITAL SERVICES, AND THE DENTAL FACILITES ARE INADEQUATELY USED. WHILE THE NUTRITION CENTERS DO A GOOD JOB OF FEEDING NOURISHING MEALS TO THE CHILDREN ENROLLED, MANY PROBLEMS EXIST. COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT SERVICES ARE HACHO'S BROADEST ACTIVITY. THEY INCLUDE CONSTRUCTION OF POTABLE WATER SYSTEMS, ROAD CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE, AND COMMUNITY COUNCILS. THE ROADS HAVE LINKED THE AREA TO THE REST OF THE NATION AND HAVE STIMULATED THE GROWTH OF REGIONAL MARKETS. THEY ARE FUNDAMENTAL TO THE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT OF THE REGION. HACHO IS CURRENTLY WORKING WITH 129 COMMUNITY COUNCILS. HACHO FIELD WORKERS BELIEVE THAT ABOUT 80 PERCENT OF THEM ARE WORKING EFFECTIVELY OR AT LEAST ACCEPTABLY. THE DIRECT IMPACT OF HACHO ON AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTIVITY HAS BEEN SLIGHT. A SURVEY INDICATES THAT, EXCLUSIVE OF FOOD COMMODITY PAYMENTS, ONLY 2.0 PERCENT HAVE BEEN SIGNIFICANTLY BENEFITED BY HACHO'S AGRICULTURAL ACTIVITIES. THE MAJOR IMPEDIMENT TO A SUCCESSFUL AGRICULTURAL PROGRAM IS THE LACK OF A WELL-DEFINED AND JUSTIFIED AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT PLAN. THE EVALUATORS MADE 36 RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT MEDICAL SERVICES, ROAD CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE, AGRICULTURE, AND COMMUNITY COUNCILS. THEY BELIEVE HACHO SHOULD BE RETAINED AS AN AUTONOMOUS REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT ORGANIZATION, BUT THAT ITS PRIORITIES SHOULD BE REORDERED AND THE ORGANIZATION RESTRUCTURED.

Abstract: THIS IS AN EXPERIMENTAL PROJECT WHICH IS SEEKING TO TEST AN INNOVATIVE GROUP-LENDING CONCEPT. WHEN THE PROJECT WAS DESIGNED, IT WAS ACKNOWLEDGED THAT IT WOULD HAVE TO BE ADJUSTED ON THE BASIS OF ACQUIRED EXPERIENCE. THIS REPORT IS PART OF THAT PROCESS. THE REPORT IS DIVIDED INTO THREE PARTS: (1)A DESCRIPTION OF THE EVALUATION METHODOLOGY; (2)THE FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE EVALUATORS; AND (3)A MORE DETAILED PRESENTATION OF THE INFORMATION USED BY THE ASSESSMENT TEAM IN REACHING ITS BASIC CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS. THE BUREAU DE CREDIT AGRICOLE (BCA) HAS BEEN SUCCESSFUL IN TAKING THE FIRST IMPORTANT STEPS TOWARD THE CREATION OF A CREDIT DELIVERY SYSTEM CAPABLE OF REACHING AND SERVICING SMALL COFFEE FARMERS IN HAITI. HOWEVER, BCA'S ACCOMPLISHMENTS FALL SHORT OF THE TARGETS ESTABLISHED FOR THE FIRST TWO YEARS OF THE PROJECT. THIS FAILURE IS TO A SIGNIFICANT DEGREE DUE TO CONDITIONS BEYOND THE CONTROL OF BCA. THE PERFORMANCE OF BCA IN IMPLEMENTING THE PROJECT THUS FAR COMES VERY CLOSE TO WHAT THE TEAM WOULD HAVE CONSIDERED TO BE REALISTIC EXPECTATIONS. THE ASSESSMENT TEAM IDENTIFIED SERIOUS FLAWS IN THE ORIGINAL DESIGN OF THE PROJECT WHICH WOULD INDICATE THAT SEVERAL OF THE PROJECT PURPOSES COULD NEVER HAVE BEEN ATTAINED. IN ADDITION, IT HAS FOUND THAT UNEXPECTED CHANGES IN SOME OF THE ASSUMPTIONS MADE FOR PROJECTION PURPOSES HAVE BEEN EXPERIENCED DURING THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROJECT. THESE FINDINGS LED TO THE CONCLUSION THAT THE PROJECT MUST BE SUBJECTED TO VERY SUBSTANTIAL REDESIGN. UNDER PRESENT CONDITIONS, THE PROJECT WOULD NOT REACH THE SERVICE TARGETS PROJECTED, AND MOST DEFINITELY, FINANCIAL VIABILITY WOULD NOT BE ATTAINED AS ORIGINALLY PROJECTED. THE EVALUATORS DISCUSSED THE FACTORS CONTRIBUTING TO THE NEED FOR PROJECT REDESIGN, THE ISSUES TO BE RESOLVED, AND ALTERNATIVE STRATEGIES FOR THE PROJECT. THEY ALSO MADE NUMEROUS RECOMMENDATIONS FOR BCA AND THE CREDIT UNION NATIONAL ASSOCIATION,AS WELL AS GENERAL PROJECT RECOMMENDATIONS.

Abstract: THE MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH AIDE (MCHA) TRAINING PROGRAM IS A WELL-DESIGNED AND CLEARLY FOCUSSED PROJECT. ALTHOUGH A YEAR BEHIND THE ORIGINAL AMBITIOUS SCHEDULE, IT HAS ALREADY RESULTED IN A SUBSTANTIAL EXPANSION OF THE CAPABILITY OF THE MINISTRY OF HEALTH TO EXTEND MCH (MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH) SERVICES TO TANZANIA'S RURAL POPULATION. FOURTEEN OF THE EIGHTEEN TRAINING CENTERS PLANNED HAVE BEEN OPENED. THE TRAINEE TARGETS ARE REALISTIC AND WILL MAKE TRAINED MCH PERSONNEL AND SERVICES ACCESSIBLE TO 90% OF THE RURAL POPULATION BY THE EARLY 1980'S. THE TANZANIA GOVERNMENT IS GIVING TOP PRIORITY TO PREVENTIVE HEALTH IN ITS TOTAL HEALTH PROGRAM, AND MCH IS GIVEN THE HIGHEST PRIORTIY AMONG ALL PREVENTIVE SERVICES. COOPERATION AMONG ALL OFFICIALS INVOLVED HAS BEEN GOOD. THE DEGREE OF EMPHASIS ON SUPPORT TO THE MCHA TRAINING PROGRAM VARIES FROM AREA TO AREA. WITH FEW EXCEPTIONS, THE COOPERATION OF MCHA SCHOOL STAFF AND THE NEARBY DISTRICT HOSPITAL STAFF APPEARED EXCELLENT. THE PLANNED UPGRADING COURSE FOR MCH PUBLIC HEALTH NURSES IS OF HIGHEST PRIORITY BECAUSE OF THE LACK OF ADEQUATE NUMBERS OF TRAINED NURSES WITH MCH AND PUBLIC HEALTH SKILLS. THROUGH FY 1976, OBLIGATIONS UNDER THIS PROJECT HAVE FUNDED THE CONSTRUCTION AND EQUIPPING OF THE EIGHTEEN SCHOOLS, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, PARTICIPANT TRAINING, EQUIPPING OF RURAL HEALTH FACILITIES, AND RECURRING COSTS WHICH WILL BE TAKEN OVER BY THE TANZANIAN GOVERNMENT. THE MCHA TRAINING PROGRAM CURRICULUM IS CONSIDERED TO BE APPROPRIATE FOR PREPARING THE MCHA'S TO WORK IN A RURAL SETTING. THE EVALUATORS DISCUSSED AND MADE 19 RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT TANZANIA, US AND OTHER DONOR SUPPORT TO THE MCHA TRAINING PROJECT; AND THE CURRICULUM, STUDENT SELECTION, SCHOOL STAFF, FIELD PRACTICE, PHYSICAL FACILITIES, AND PARTICIPANT TRAINING ASPECTS OF THE PROGRAM.

OCEAC'S (ORGANIZATION FOR THE CONTROL OF ENDEMIC DISEASES IN CENTRAL AFRICA) PARTICIPATION IN THE PROJECT FROM THE BEGINNING HAS BEEN A MATTER OF CONVENIENCE DESIGNED TO MEET AID'S REQUIREMENTS. HOWEVER, WHETHER OR NOT HEALTH EDUCATION ACTIVITIES WILL CONTINUE AS A PART OF HEALTH SERVICES IS UNCERTAIN. IN SUMMARY, THE GREATEST VALUES OF THIS PROJECT LIE IN ITS INTRODUCTION OF THE HEALTH EDUCATION CONCEPT TO HEATLH WORKERS IN THREE COUNTRIES, THE TRAINING OF A SMALL GROUP OF NATIONAL COUNTERPARTS, AND, MOST OF ALL, IN THE NEGATIVE LESSONS FROM THE CONCEPTION, DEVELOPMENT, OPERATION, AND EVALUATION OF THIS PROJECT. Abstract: CERFER (CENTRE REGIONAL DE FORMATION POUR L'ENTRETIEN ROUTIER) IS AN OPERATIONAL AND REASONABLY SELF-SUFFICIENT AFRICAN HEAVY EQUIPMENT AND ROAD MAINTENANCE TRAINING CENTER. CERFER'S SOLE AND LIMITED PURPOSE IS TO PREPARE MECHANICS, FOREMEN, AND WAREHOUSE/MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL IN PRACTICAL SKILLS FOR THEIR DAY-TO-DAY JOBS ON SECONDARY ROAD EQUIPMENT. HEAVY EQUIPMENT OPERATORS ARE NO LONGER TRAINED AT CERFER. CERFER IS CAPABLE OF TRAINING APPROXIMATELY 160 STUDENTS ANNUALLY AND COULD PROBABLY TRAIN UP TO 180. CERFER HAS A SUFFICENTLY BRIGHT FINANCIAL OUTLOOK TO CONTINUE WITHOUT AID ASSISTANCE. ITS OPERATIONAL BUDGET WILL BE COVERED BY REVENUES FROM THE ENTENTE STATES; ITS INVESTMENT BUDGET FROM NON-ENTENTE STUDENTS FINANCED BY OTHER AFRICAN COUNTRIES, OUTSIDE DONORS, AND, AS NEEDED, BY SERVICES RENDERED. THE TECHNIQUES USED BY CERFER TO ACHIEVE AFRICANIZATION MAY HAVE VALIDITY FOR SIMILAR TRANSFERS OF RESPONSIBILITIES IN ANALOGOUS SITUATIONS. DURING THE ENTIRE PERIOD, CERFER GRADUATED 1,370 STUDENTS, 919 OF THEM BETWEEN 1970 AND 1976. WITH MINOR EXCEPTIONS, EVERY IMPORTANT SPECIFIC ACTION PROPOSED IN 1974 AND 1975 HAS BEEN TAKEN: AFRICANIZATION OF CERFER STAFF; EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL AND BUDGETARY CONTROLS; INSTALLATION OF EQUIPMENT-USE AND PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE SYSTEMS; REPAIR AND SALE OF USABLE EQUIPMENT; EVALUATION OF THE MOBILE UNIT CONCEPT; REVISION OF COURSES TO MAKE THEM MORE PRACTICAL; AND PROMPT PAYMENT OF CONTRIBUTIONS BY THE ENTENTE STATES. THE EVALUATORS MADE 8 RECOMMENDATIONS REGARDING PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION OF SIMILAR PROJECTS IN THE FUTURE AS WELL AS RECOMMENDATIONS FOR CERFER'S FUTURE ACTIVITIES AND ADMINISTRATION. THEIR OVERALL CONCLUSION WAS THAT DESPITE FAILURE TO OBTAIN MAXIMUM PERFORMANCE DURING EARLIER YEARS, CERFER -- AT PROJECT END -- REPRESENTS A WORTHY AID ACHIEVEMENT, WHEN COMPARED WITH OTHER SIMILAR INSTITUTIONS AND PROJECT OBJECTIVES.

Abstract: THIS REPORT IS PHASE I OF A TWO-PHASE EVALUATION. THE FY76 ACCELERATED IMPACT PROGRAM (AIP) HAD EXPERIENCED DIFFICULTIES AND WAS BEHIND SCHEDULE DESPITE SUBSTANTIAL ADVANCE PLANNING AND THE WIDESPREAD DISSEMINATION OF THE AID CRITERIA AND DETAILED PROCEDURES. AS OF SEPTEMBER 30, 1976, ONLY $2.3 MILLION OF THE $5 MILLION PROGRAMMED WAS OBLIGATED FOR 17 ACTIVITIES IN 5 OF THE SAHEL COUNTRIES. DESPITE EXTENSIVE EXPERIENCE WITH SIMILAR SAHEL R&R PROCEDURES AND LENGTHY PREPARATIONS FOR THE AIP PROGRAM, IT WAS PERHAPS OVERAMBITIOUS TO EXPECT $5 MILLION IN OBLIGATIONS WITHIN A NINE-MONTH PERIOD. AIP WAS A NEW PROGRAM REQUIRING MORE DELIBERATE AND INTENSIVE DESIGN EFFORTS THAT R&R AND ALSO A CONSIDERABLY LARGER AID/W ROLE IN REVIEW, PROCESSING AND MONITORING. AIP PROGRAM DELAYS AND DEFICIENCIES WERE ATTRIBUTABLE TO TWO MAIN FACTORS: (1)VAGUENESS AND CONFUSION ABOUT AIP CRITERIA; AND (2)INADEQUATE DETAIL IN THE A-PID SUBMISSIONS. ALTHOUGH A SMALL NUMBER OF APPROVED AIP ACTIVITIES DID CONFORM TO THE LIMITS ORIGINALLY PROPOSED, I.E., PILOT, START-UP OR INNOVATIVE, THE BULK OF APPROVED ACTIVITIES FOR FY76 APPEARD TO FIT MORE NEARLY WITH IN THE EARLIER IMMEDIATE IMPACT CRITERIA FOR THE R&R PROGRAM FRAMEWORK. FOR FY77, HOWEVER, AFR/SFWA MISSIONS HAVE INDICATED THAT PILOT AND START-UP ACTIVITIES ARE APPROPRIATE TO THE SAHEL DEVELOPMENTAL SITUATION. THE EVALUATORS BELIEVE THE BASIC AIP PROGRAM OBJECTIVES AND CORRESPONDING CRITERIA REMAIN SOUND AND VALID. ORIGINALLY, ONE-TIME AFR/W APPROVAL OF DISAPPROVAL WAS TO BE BASED UPON THE REVIEW AND PROCESSING OF THE A-PID. HOWEVER, THE A-PID'S DID NOT CONTAIN SUFFICIENT INFORMATION AND THE REVIEW AND APPROVAL PROCESS STRETCHED OVER SEVERAL MONTHS. THE EVALUATORS MADE EIGHT GENERAL RECOMMENDATIONS AND NINE RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT AIP PROCEDURES,INCLUDING THAT AIP SHOULD BE CONTINUED IN AFRICA IN FY77 AND FY78 AND THAT IT SHOULD CONCENTRATE ON SMALL-SCALE PILOT, START-UP AND INNOVATIVE ACTIVITIES.

Abstract: THE AGRICULTURAL PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT PROJECT HAS MADE SUBSTANTIAL PROGRESS IN ACCOMPLISHING ITS STATED PURPOSE. ACHIEVEMENTS BY SPECIFIED SUBAREAS HAVE VARIED CONSIDERABLY IN QUANTITATIVE RESPECTS, HOWEVER, AND QUALITATIVE PERFORMANCE CAN BE EVALUATED ONLY AGAINST STATEMENTS OF EXPECTATIONS THAT ARE SUBJECT TO INTERPRETATION. THE OUTPUT TARGET FOR DATA COLLECTION AND TABULATION HAS BEEN ACCOMPLISHED IN GENEROUS MEASURE, AS REFLECTED BY COMPLETION OF THE 1974 AND 1975 RICE SURVEYS, INITIATION OF THE 1976 RICE SURVEY, AND PUBLICATION OF THE STATISTICAL HANDBOOK. EXCEPT THAT THE RETURN OF PARTICIPANTS HAS LAGGED BEHIND THE TARGET COMPLETION DATE, THE ATTAINMENT OF FUNCTIONAL CAPABILITY HAS EXCEEDED ORIGINAL EXPECTATIONS. THE RANGE OF FIELDS OF TRAINING IS HELPING TO CREATE A BALANCED CAPABILITY FOR PRODUCING STATISTICAL DATA, CONDUCTING ECONOMIC STUDIES, AND PREPARING AND EVALUATING DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS. DURING THE PLANNING DIVISION'S RELATIVELY SHORT EXISTENCE IT HAS MADE UNCOMMON PROGRESS TOWARD EFFECTIVE OPERATION IN SEVERAL OF ITS AREAS OF RESPONSIBILITY. ITS PRESENT WORK DEMONSTRATES PRIOR COMPLETION OF A RUDIMENTARY ANALYTICAL FOUNDATION, ALTHOUGH A COMPREHENSIVE SECTOR ANALYSIS REMAINS TO BE PREPARED AND IS URGENLTY NEEDED. THE PROJECT HAS SUCCEEDED IN PRODUCING A TENUOUS CAPABILITY FOR CONDUCTING RATHER DETAILED SOIL SURVEYS. THE BROAD RESPONSIBILITIES AND THE LIMITED TRAINING OF THE PLANNING DIVISION'S STAFF OUTSIDE THE STATISTICS SECTION PLACE SHARP LIMITS ON ITS CAPABILITY AND PERFORMANCE IN DEVELOPING AND APPRAISING INDIVIDUAL PROJECTS, FITTING THESE TOGETHER IN ANNUAL AND LONG-TERM PROGRAMS RESPONSIVE TO THE NEEDS OF THE SECTOR, AND DEVELOPING THE KIND OF SECTOR ANALYSIS NEEDED AS A FRAMEWORK FOR THE FOREGOING ACTIVITIES. MOST TARGETS WILL HAVE BEEN ATTAINED BY THE END OF THE PROJECT, BUT THE RESULTING INSTITUTIONAL CAPABILITY MAY BE MORE TENUOUS THAN IS DESIRED. THE EVALUATORS MADE 12 RECOMMENDATONS ABOUT A FOLLOW-ON PROJECT.

Abstract: NOT A PES. REGIONAL ROAD MAINTENANCE TRAINING CENTER (RRMTC), ALSO CALLED CERFER, GRADUATED 1370 STUDENTS. STUDENT COST PER MONTH WAS AT A NORMAL LEVEL FOR AID TRAINING. BOTTLENECKS WHICH HINDERED OR SLOWED PROJECT GROWTH INCLUDE: 1)LACK OF BURDEN-SHARING AND SELF-HELP REQUIREMENTS IN GHE GRANT AGREEMENTS DETERRED INITIATIVE; 2)LACK OF PARTICIPATION OF RECIPIENTS AT COUNCIL-OF ADMINISTRATION AND DIRECTOR-GENERAL LEVEL REDUCED INCENTIVES TO MEET SPECIFIED OBJECTIVES. 3)LACK OF CONTINUING CONTACT WITH USER-COUNTRIES HAMPERS CERFER'S ABILITY TO MEET THEIR NEEDS; 4)REQUIREMENT THAT EQUIPMENT BE OF US ORIGIN, AND DECISION TO USE (NON-COMPATIBLE) SECTION 608 EQUIPMENT, REDUCED TRAINING EFFICIENCY AND DIVERTED INSTRUCTION; 5)DESIRE OF ENTENTE STATES TO KEEP EXPERTS AT HOME GENERALLY RESTRICTS CERFER'S STAFF TO TOGOLESE; 6)DIFFERENCES IN DONOR PHILOSOPHIES RESULTED IN DIVERGENT APPROACHES TO INSTRUCTION; 7) AERO-FORD REPRESENTED AID, BUT GENERALLY FAILED TO MEET CONTRACT OBJECTIVES DURING FIRST 4 YEARS. A-F (A) DID NOT RECRUIT ON TIME; (B) HAD UNUSUALLY HIGH TURNOVER OF ADVISORS (EG, 4 CHIEFS-OF-PARTY SINCE 1970); (C) LACKED SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES AND PROCEDURES AT THE BEGINNING; AND (D) DID NOT DEVELOP SYSTEMS AND COUNTERPARTS UNTIL LATE IN THE CONTRACT. CORRESPONDINGLY AID FAILED TO HOLD CONTRACTOR TO THE AGREEMENT; 8) SERVICE WORK AND RENTAL OF EQUIPMENT ADVERSELY AFFECTED INSTRUCTION. AID SHOULD ASSURE DEVELOPMENT OF COUNTERPARTS AND SYSTEMS FROM THE START; SHOULD REQUIRE ENTRY/EXIT REPORTS FROM ALL CONTRACT ADVISORS; SHOULD PHASE OUT CONTRACTOR'S ADVISORS ON STAGGERED BASIS SO ONE MGMT ADVISOR COULD REMAIN AS A SOUNDING BOARD TO CERFER'S STAFF. CERFER SHOULD PROVIDE MORE ADMINISTRATIVE CONTINUITY; BETTER EVALUATION OF GRADUATES TO PROVIDE BASIS FOR TAILORING SYSTEMS; MORE SEMINARS AND ADD1 PUBLICITY. HOWEVER, DESPITE FAILURE TO OBTAIN MAXIMUM PERFORMANCE, CERFER REPRESENTS A WORTHY AID ACHIEVEMENT MEASURED BY PROP OBJECTIVES.

Abstract: AID-ORGANIZED TEAM CONDUCTED FEASIBILITY REVIEW OF PREVIOUS CHECCHI COMPANY,LIBERIAN RURAL ROADS STUDY WHICH HAD BEEN JUDGED BY AID REVIEWERS TO BE DEFICIENT IN ITS ANALYSIS. AID TEAM CONCLUDED THAT CHECCHI OFFERED INADEQUATE SUPPORT OF IDENTIFIED IMPACT AREAS AND A SUPERFICIAL ANALYSIS OF CONSTRUCTION COSTS. THE AID TEAM ALSO NOTED CHANGES IN THE STATUS OF THE THREE PROJECT COMPONENTS EXAMINED BY CHECCHI: THE LIBERIAN GOVERNMENT HAD SUBSTANTIALLY COMPLETED THE BUCHANAN-RIVER CESS ROUTE WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE TIMBO RIVER BRIDGE; UPGRADING OF BREWERVILLE-BOPULU ROAD SEGMENT JUDGED AS NOT MEETING AID'S DEVELOPMENT CRITERIA; THE TEAM THUS FOCUSED ITS ATTENTION ON THE PR0POSED 108-MILE NEW ROUTE FROM BOPULU THROUGH BELLE YELLA TO KONIA,EXAMING THE ROUTE AS A WHOLE,AS WELL AS EACH SEGMENT SEPARATELY, AID ASSISTANCE WITH THE TIMBO RIVER BRIDGE WAS ALSO CONSIDERED BY THE TEAM. AID TEAM REJECTS CONSIDERATION OF TIMBO RIVER BRIDGE DUE TO LACK OF DESIGN WORK AND A SUBSURFACE SOIL INVESTIGATION BY THE LIBERIAN GOVT AND RECOMMENDS ON THE BASIS OF ITS COSTS-BENEFITS ANALYSIS THAT ONLY THE SOUTHERN BOPULU-BELLE YELLA SEGMENT OF THE BOPULU-KONIA ROUTE BE CONSIDERED FOR AID SUPPORT. THIS RECOMMENDATION IS MADE CONTINGENT ON A REDESIGN OF THE ROUTE BY THE MINISTRY OF PUBLIC WORKS WITH A DOWNGRADING FROM ITS CURRENT PRIMARY STATUS TO A SECONDARY,CLASS B RURAL ROAD. A CONSIDERABLE REDUCTION IN PREVIOUS COST ESTIMATES IS THUS ANTICIPATED. TEAM ADDITIONALLY RECOMMENDS AID GRANT FOR SIMULTANEOUS STUDY/DESIGN OF SECONDARY LINKING ROADS NORTH,WEST AND EAST OF THE PROPOSED BELLE YELLA TERMINUS. ANNEXES INCLUDE IMPACT AREA ANALYSIS,COST-BENEFIT TABLES,MAPS,AND A BIBLIOGRAPHY.

Abstract: EVALUATES THE ACHIEVEMENTS IN RESEARCH, PROJECTS, AND WORKSHOPS OF THE AFRICAN-AMERICAN SCHOLARS COUNCIL, INC (AASC) FROM 1971 TO JAN 1976. NOT ENOUGH ATTENTION WAS GIVEN TO JOINT AFRICAN/AMERICAN RESEARCH. THE PROJECT REVIEW/SELECTION PROCESS DURING THE FIRST 3 YEARS OF THE GRANT DID NOT INVOLVE HOST COUNTRIES AND MISSIONS. THE AASC COUNCIL AND BOARD OF DIRECTORS LACKED A MECHANISM FOR SCREENING AND APPROVING RESEARCH PROPOSALS UP TO 1974. THE AASC COUNCIL WAS WEAK IN STUDYING NEW APPROACHES TO SATISFYING AFRICAN NEEDS AND NOT ALL OF THE COUNCIL WAS INVOLVED IN REVIEW. AFTER 1974, REVIEW CRITERIA BEGAN TO INCLUDE 1) CONGRESSIONAL MANDATES, 2) POTENTIAL CONTRIBUTION TO THE SOLUTION OF AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT PROBLEMS, 3) CLARITY AND COMPLETENESS OF DESIGN, AND 4) HOST COUNTRY INTERESTS AND NEEDS. BETTER OUTCOMES RESULTED FROM WORKSHOPS AND CONFERENCES ALTHOUGH COMPARABLE OUTCOMES MAY HAVE RESULTED FOR LESS COST HAD ACTIVITIES AND PROCEDURES BEEN DIFFERENT. THE COUNCIL NEEDS A SYSTEM OF MEMBERSHIP TURNOVER TO PREVENT ORGANIZATIONAL INEFFICIENCY. Abstract: Evaluates end of project status of the North Carolina State Univ Agricultural Diversification & Trade project as of 4/76.  Review team focused on accomplishments, work methods & recommendations. With available rsrch findings, the project leader could neither analyze alternative means & costs of transporting & distributing vegetables from production zones nor evaluate domestic demand & consumption compared with export demand.  Project leader also found that vegetable storage & preservation could become important if domestic per capita income & employment increased.  However, lack of domestic demand for fresh vegetables precludes using statistical estimates at present. Alternative commodity transport to export markets & quality control cost returns need evaluation. Export market potential estimates must incorporate cost & volume effects of tariffs & quotas.  At ten times production cost, export marketing is high risk, and the exporter bears the entire cost of price decline, spoilage loss, waiting time, and market close-out.  Export expansion depends on 50% yield increases, 50% reduced production costs, introduction of quality control, volume markets, and large scale operations integration. Knowledge of markets, prices, and trade terms is required in comparative advantage studies of economic alternatives.  Phase I could have better established how vegetable production really was & its direction; then could have better judged what needed to be found out & how to find it.  Some data & country participation expectations were unfeasible.  Small farmer participation could have been ruled out.  The statistical demand estimation models and the quadratic programming model containing vegetable production & demand function data for various countries need to be explained to LDC planners. Recommendations are to distribute a technical appendix explanation of the demand estimation model and prepare a digest of project materials.

Abstract: EVALUATES THE EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND EDUCATOR TRAINING PROGRAM (AS OF 12/1/76) DEVELOPED UNDER THE RADIOPHONIC SCHOOLS COMPONENT OF THE NICARAGUAN RURAL COMMUNITY HEALTH SERVICES PROJ (PRACS). THE RADIOPHONIC SCHOOLS COMPONENT UTILIZES RADIO INSTRUCTION IN CONJUNCTION WITH CLASSROOM DISCUSSION TO INFORM COMMUNITY MEMBERS OF BENEFICIAL HEALTH AND HYGIENE PRACTICES WHILE PROVIDING EXPERIENTIAL TRAINING TO HEALTH EDUCATORS IN RADIOPHONIC TEACHING METHODS. THIS EVAL WAS CONDUCTED BY  INTERVIEWING KEY SCHOOL PERSONNEL AND STUDYING PROJ REPORTS AND THE MATERIAL DEVELOPED (TAPES, RADIO SCRIPTS, FLIP CHARTS). RADIO SCRIPTS AND VISUAL MATERIALS WERE DEVELOPED BY THE STUDENT HEALTH EDUCATORS AND TRIED OUT ON EACH OTHER. THE LACK OF PRE-TESTING OF THESE MATERIALS ON A SAMPLE TARGET AUDIENCE AND FOLLOW-UP REVISION RESULTED IN SEVERAL OF THE COMPLETED MATLS BEING EXCESSIVELY LONG, SOMETIMES INCOMPREHENSIBLE, AND OVERLY COMPLEX FOR THE INTENDED AUDIENCE. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT, IN THE FUTURE, PRE-TESTING BE UNDERTAKEN. THE MATLS THUS FAR DEVELOPED COULD BE IMPROVED OR REGARDED SIMPLY AS PRACTICE WORK FOR FUTURE ACTIVITIES. ALSO, AN A/V AND COMMUNICATIONS EXPERT COULD BE CONTRACTED TO CONDUCT A SHORT WORKSHOP FOR HEALTH EDUCATORS IN EDUCATIONAL MATLS PRODUCTION. AN EVALUATION OF THE RADIOPHONIC SCHOOLS AS A TRAINING TOOL FOR HEALTH EDUCATORS HAS NOT BEEN UNDERTAKEN. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT TESTS BE CONDUCTED OF STUDENT ATTITUDES TOWARDS THE USE OF SUCH NON-TRADITIONAL HEALTH EDUCATION METHODS BEFORE AND AFTER THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE RADIOPHONIC SCHOOLS.

Abstract: EVALUATES 211 (D) GRANT TO STANFORD UNIVERSITY TO STRENGTHEN THE UNIVERSITY'S CAPABILITY AS A CENTER FOR RESEARCH AND TRAINING IN LAW AND DEVELOPMENT FROM 5/71 TO 10/76. THE PRIMARY RESEARCH TASK WAS THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A DATA BASE OF LEGAL AND SOCIAL INDICATORS IN 6 COUNTRIES HAVING A MEDITERRANEAN TYPE OF LEGAL SYSTEM. THESE DATA WERE TO BE TRANSFERRED INTO A COMPUTE FORMAT, ANALYZED, AND MANUSCRIPTS WERE TO BE PREPARED. THE DATA COLLECTION EFFORT IS ESSENTIALLY COMPLETE, BUT THE RESEARCH PRODUCTS WILL NOT BE COMPLETED WITHIN THE PLANNED FIVE-YEAR TERM. ALTHOUGH AID HAS DECIDED NOT TO EXTEND ITS INVOLVEMENT IN THE PROJECT BY PROVIDING ADDITIONAL FUNDING, THE EVALUATION TEAM IS CONFIDENT THAT THE RESEARCH PRODUCTS WILL BE COMPLETED, BECAUSE OF THE PROFESSIONAL AND PERSONAL COMMITMENT MADE BY KEY PROFESSORS INVOLVED IN THE PROJECT. BECAUSE THE QUALITY AND POSSIBLE IMPORTANCE OF RESEARCH CANNOT BE EVALUATED UNTIL KEY VOLUMES ARE AVAILABLE FOR REVIEW, NO HARD JUDGEMENTS COULD BE MADE ABOUT THE QUALITY AND IMPORTANCE OF AID INVESTMENT IN THE PROJECT AT THIS TIME. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT AID CONTINUE TO MONITOR THE RESEARCH PRODUCTS AND SEEK TO ESTABLISH A TIMETABLE FOR FINISHING KEY VOLUMES AND COUNTRY STUDIES. IT IS ALSO RECOMMENDED THAT A FURTHER EVALUATION OF THE RESEARCH ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT BE CONDUCTED. THE EVALUATION TEAM ALSO NOTED SEVERAL INSIGHTS CONCERNING THE GRANT WHICH MAY BE OF USE IN DEVELOPING, MONITORING, AND EVALUATING OTHER 211(D) GRANTS. THESE INCLUDE: 1)THE AGENCY SHOULD RECOGNIZE THE UNIVERSITY BIAS FOR BASIC RESEARCH AND THE FACT THAT THE UNIV AND AID HAVE DIFFERENT INTERESTS; 2)IN DEVELOPING SIMILAR PROJECTS, AGREEMENT SHOULD BE REACHED IN PRECISE TERMS ABOUT EXPECTED OUTPUTS; 3)GRANT AGREEMENTS SHOULD ADDRESS TIMETABLES AND SCHEDULING TO ASSURE TIMELY PROJ COMPLETION;4)ALL APPROVED CHANGES IN PROJECT EMPHASIS SHOULD BE DOCUMENTED;5)IN PROVIDING GRANTS IN FIELDS WHERE KNOWLEDGE IS LIMITED, SPECIAL PROJECT MONITORING AND EVALUATION ARRANGEMENTS SHOULD BE ESTABLISHED. CONCLUDES THAT THE PROJ WAS AN APPROPRIATE USE OF AID FUNDS, & IT SHOWS SIGNS OF CONTRIBUTING TO OUR UNDERSTANDING OF LEGAL SYS WORKING.

Abstract: Evaluates project performance from 4/76 to 11/76 in Indonesia.  USAID assists the Govt of Indonesia prepare the Luwu area for transmigration by improving its transportation system, developing irrigation areas. establishing health facilities, and providing agricultural assistance and community development training.  Evaluation is based on visits to 3 regional offices, meetings with sub-project bodies, and on-site observation. Evaluator feels project has outstanding possibilities for integrated development of resources and people if administrative obstacles can be overcome.  The various projects are still operating as sector programs with little commitment by agencies and lack of team work.  This divided authority makes delays and disruptions inevitable. The greatest need is to strengthen the Project Manager's position by giving him authority over budgets and all personnel.  Project manager should also receive more timely technical advice and divide his time equally between office and field work.  The special advisor needs to develop an area regional plan taking into account alternative development. It is estimated that the Luwu area has the potential to absorb up to 40,000 transmigrant families engaged in irrigation, fish farming, horticultural specialities, and service industries.  Before transmigrant families can be placed, however, a future water supply to maintain the area must be assured; further planning of water, mineral, and forest resources uses made; and Bina Marga's delay to begin the physical work on roads and irrigation mapping overcome.  It is recommended that an immediate engineering feasibility study of several low head streams as potential water storage reservoirs and hydro-electric power producers be made with forestry department responsible for the watershed of the irrigation supply streams.  Since project implementation also depends on trained personnel, arrangements are being made with the Ford Foundation and Community Development Society of North America to train community members as extension workers to work with transmigrant villages through self-help activities and acceptance of change.

Abstract: EVALAUTES PROGRM OF APPLIED RSRCH ON FERTILITY CONTROL (PARFR0 FROM 11/74 TO 6/76, BASED ON PROJECT CO-MONITOR ACTIVITIES, SCIENTIFIC ADVISORY COMMITTEE (SAC) FINDINGS & VISITS TO PARFR. FEMALE STERLZTN, EXPECIALLY HYSTEROSCOPY, HAS BEEN STUDIED IN COORDNTD RSRCH INCLUDNG A 1973 WRKSHP, FUNDING FOR PROMISING HYSTEROSCOPIC RSRCHPROJCTS, INITIATN OF HYSTEROSCOPIC REGISTRY TO ASSEMBLE INFO ON WORLDWIDE CLINICAL EXPERIENCE WITH THE METHOD,& A FOLLOW-UP FEMALE STER WRKSHP IN 1975. UTEROTUBAL BLOCKING METHODS ARE UNDERGOING HUMAN TRAILS. ALSO PROMISING IS BLIND TRANSCEICAL APPROACH UTILIZNG MCA, A TISSUE GLUE. LONG-ACTING DRUG DELIV SYSTMS & STUDIES OF NEW PHARMACOLOGICAL AGENTS, 2 OF WHICH, OF 8 STUDIED, ARE VIABLE(AN END-ORGAN SPECIFC CHEMICAL AGENT & AN ANTIGONADOTROPIC EXTRACT OF PINEAL GLAND) & BEING DEVELOPD. STUDIES OF IUD'S USING COPPER & IUD'S RELEASING AN ANTIFIBRINOLYTIC AGENT, EACA, ARE BEING STUDIED. SUPPORT FOR IUD'S OTHER THAN INERT IUD'S HAS BEEN TERMINATD. A FEMALE LOCAL METHOD USING AN ODORLESS COLLAGEN SPONGE & A MALE METHOD OF TRANSCUTANEOUS INJECTN OF SCLEROSING AGENTS INTO THE VAS DEFERENS HAVE BEEN DEEMED PROMISING WITH RSRCH EXTENDED. NEW APPROACHES TO REVERSIBLE MALE CONTRACEPTION ARE ALSO BEING SUPPORTD. WHILE IMMUNOLOGY & PREG TERMIN HAVE BEGUN TO BE SUPPORTD, STUDIES OF ROLE OF ANTIBODIES IN VASECTOMY & VASOVASOSTOMY DESERVE MORE ATTENTN AS ONLY 1 PROJCT STUDYNG POST-COITAL CONTRACEPTIVE EFFECT OF IUD INSERTN HAS BEEN FUNDED. A COLLABORATIVE CLINICAL RSRCH CNTR ESTABLISHED IN AN LDC WILL PROMOTE TESTING OF TECHNOLOGICAL DEVICES & SPREAD THEIR UTILIZATION. PARFR IS TECHNICALLY UNDERSTAFFED AND HAS PRODUCED FEWER PROJECTS THAN HOPED FOR. LDC'S HAVE MADE FEW FUNDABLE PROJECT PROPOSALS. PARFR NEEDS TO ACTIVELY RECRUIT FOREIGNERS STUDYING IN THE US AS POTENTIAL GRANTEES UPON THEIR RETURN TO NATIVE COUNTRIES.

Abstract: EVALUATES TWO URBAN AND REGIONAL SECTOR LOANS FOR THE PERIOD 8/71 TO 11/76 IN COLOMBIA (PROJECT NUMBERS 5140163 AND 5140172.) OBJECTIVES OF THE FIRST LOAN INCLUDE THE PROMOTION OF ECONOMIC GROWTH IN INTERMEDIATE-SIZED CITIES AND THE IMPROVEMENT OF BASIC INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES TO LOW-INCOME AREAS IN FOUR MAJOR CITIES. THE FOLLOW-ON LOAN ADDED SEVERAL OT HER GOALS, EMPHASIZING THE PROMOTION OF LABOR-INTENSIVE INDUSTRY. EVALUATION IS BASED ON AVAILABLE DATA COMPILED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF NATIONAL PLANNING (DNP). THE ADMINISTRATIVE COMPLEXITY OF THE TWO LOANS MADE EVALUATION DIFFICULT. FOUR AGENCIES WERE INVOLVED IN IMPLEMENTING THE FIRST LOAN AND SEVEN AGENCIES WERE INVOLVED IN IMPLEMENTING THE SECOND LOAN. THIS PLACED A HEAVEY BURDEN ON THE COORDINATIVE FUNCTION WHICH FELL TO DNP. BUT DNP HAD NO OPERATIONAL ROLE AND CAME TOO LATE TO THE TASK.  THUS, INDIVIDUAL INVESTMENTS WERE NOT WELL COORDINATED WITH THE LOANS' SECTOR OBJECTIVES. IN ADDITION, THE LACK OF CLEAR THEORIES OF URBAN AND REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT CONTRIBUTED TO THE PRESENCE OF CONFLICTING OR POORLY CONCEIVED OBJECTIVES IN THE LOANS. FOR INSTANCE, THE LOANS SOUGHT TO PROMOTE ECONOMIC GROWTH IN INTERMEDIATE CITIES AS WELL AS TO IMPROVE THE FLOW OF CREDIT TO SMALL LABOR INTENSIVE INDUSTRIES. IN FACT, SMALL INDUSTRIES AND LABOR-INTENSIVE INDUSTRIES ARE LIKELY TO BE BETTER REPRESENTED IN THE LARGEST CITIES THAN IN INTERMEDIATE CITIES. THE EVALUATION PRESENTS LITTLE EVIDENCE OF THE LOANS' TOTAL IMPACT ON URBAN AND REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT IN COLOMBIA. THE AUTHOR DID, HOWEVER, CONSTRUCT VARIOUS STATISTICAL TESTS USING DATA ON HAND AT DNP. REGRESSION ANALYSES SHOWED A STRONG RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE INVESTMENTS FINANCED BY THE CREDITS AND THE VALUE ADDED AND EMPLOYMENT IN THE RECIPIENT CITIES. NO DIRECT CAUSATION IS IMPLIED HOWEVER, ANALYSIS OF EXPENDITURE PATTERNS SUGGEST THAT THE USAID-SUPPORTED CREDIT WAS NOT TOTALLY USED FOR FINANCING OF "PRIORITY EXPANSION AREAS OF THE GOC'S URBAN/REGIONAL STRATEGY". THE DNP HAD FAILED TO RANK PRIORITY INVESTMENTS, OR AT LEAST NOT PUBLICLY. AND WHAT RANKING DID EXIST HAD NO CLEAR RELATION TO URBAN DEVELOPMENT STRATEGY.

Abstract: Evaluates effectiveness of loans and grants in supporting an animal vaccine laboratory in Mali from 1962 to 1976.  Evaluatn team conducted a 2 week onsite evaluatn at Bamaro and 2 field stations, and performed a project analysis based on widely dispersed basic documents.  The Project was designed to:  1. diagnose animal diseases, 2. make vaccines to fight pleuropneumonia.Rinderpest, anthrax.pasteurella, and black leg; and 3.do research in regional animal disease. Vaccines for only the first 2 diseases are made in sufficient quantity to meet Mali's needs, due to an inadequate operating budget. Evaluator recommends increased quality controls (sterility control, pyrogeneity testing, and in-vivo testing of vaccine), and increased production of short-supply items and aviary vaccines. Establishment of priorities is also recommended for medium-range efforts in diagnosis and research, as is a conference of African countries aimed at coordinating laboratory functions and facilities in order to avoid duplication. Evaluator recommends investigation of the Central Veterinary Lab (CVL) by a specialist in occupational hazards of vaccine laboratories to avoid accidents like the 1974 explosion which resulted in disfigurement of personnel. Financial and procedural recommendations are aimed at seeking means of economizing and of supplementing finances, and at maintaining basic documents for periodic audit.  Negotiations with contractors have been beset by many problems due to inappropriate decisions, designs, and clearances, as well as to contractor's failures.  A notable exception was a maintenance contract with the Organization of Rehabilitation and Training which trained local personnel in repair and maintenance of CVL equipment. Investigation has determined that CVL's finances have been overburdened by association with the Ministry of Health Solution Production Lab.  This association has also overburdened the available water supply and led to the 1974 explosion.  Evaluator states that further efforts such as the tse tse research in "Mali Livestock 2" represents too great a drain on CVL's finances and facilities.
