Abstract: JAN 1976 INTERIM EVAL REPORT CONDUCTED BY AMERICAN PUBLIC HEALTH ASSOCIATION TEAM OF FY73-FY78 AFRICAN HEALTH TRNG INSTITUTIONS PROJ (AHTIP). PROJ DESIGNED TO PROMOTE FAMILY PLANNING (FP) AS ACCEPTED COMPONENT OF TRNG AT AFRICAN HEALTH TRAINING INSTITUTIONS (HTI'S) THROUGH UPGRADING AND TRAINING OF HEALTH PROFESSIONALS & INFLUENCING CURRICULUM DVLP. TEAM UTILIZED LARGELY QUALITATIVE CRITERIA IN ONSITE MEETINGS WITH AHTIP PROJ STAFF AT THE CAROLINA POPULATION CENTER OF THE UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA-CHAPEL HILL (UNC) AND WITH HTI REPRESENTATIVES IN GHANA, EGYPT, NIGERIA, SUDAN, AND KENYA; ADDITIONAL CORRESPONDENCE WAS CONDUCTED WITH 8 AFRICAN HTI LEADERS. TEAM FOUND THAT FP GOALS OF PROJ HAD BEEN DEVELOPED AND PRESENTED UNDER GUISE OF FAMILY HEALTH,DUE TO STRONG POLITICAL & CULTURAL SENSITIVITIES;AS A RESULT,PITFALLS HAVE BEEN SIDESTEPPED,BUT DIRECTION OF ORIGINAL CONTRACT ALTERED. FP GOALS HAVE NOT BEEN PURSUED WITH VIGOR. AHTIP STAFF ARE LARGELY EDUCATION SPECIALISTS WITH PART-TIME UNC DUTIES;DESPITE DVLP OF EDUCATIONAL COMPONENTS AND OF EXCELLENT RELATIONSHIPS WITH AFRICAN HTI LEADERS,A CRITICAL MASS OF SKILL & COMMITMENT IS LACKING. AHTIP STAFF'S SELF-INSTRUCTIONAL UNITS(SI'S) ARE JUDGED OUTMODED & DISAPPOINTING IN FP AREA;SHOULD BE CULTURALLY ATTUNED,AND MORE EMPHASIS SHOULD BE PLACED ON DVLP OF CASE HISTORIES,DEEMED TO BE MORE EFFECTIVE,WITH AN INCREASED BUDGED OVERALL FOR TEACHING MATERIALS. WORKSHOPS NEED ADEQUATE FOLLOW-UP REINFORCEMENT;SHOULD BE CONDUCTED IN COUNTRIES WITH HIGH FP AWARENESS. MAJOR PROB IS INERTIA IN DVLP OF AUXILIARY HEALTH WORKER TRNG;CHIEF AHTIP LIASON HAS BEEN WITH ASSOC OF MEDICAL SCHOOLS IN AFRICA(AMSA) WHICH HAS OFFERED LITTLE SUPPORT FOR AUXILIARY TRNG. TEAM RECOMMENDS SOLID EFFORTS TO ASSIST NON-PHYSICIAN HTI'S EXTENSION OF PROJ SCOPE TO VAST FRANCOPHONE AREA AND PRECIPITOUS TRANSFER OF AHTIP WORK TO AFRICA WITH CONTINUING UNC CONSULTANT BACKUP. PROJ MIGHT THEN BE ADMINISTERED THROUGH AMSA AND WHO WITH SUPPORT OF OTHER INTERN DONOR AGENCIES SOUGHT TO EXPAND PROJ SCOPE. VACANT FIELD DIR POST SHOULD BE FILLED BY BILINGUAL(ANGLO/FRANCO) AFRICAN. LIASON SHOULD BE ESTAB WITH OTHER AID FAMILY PLANNING PROJS.

Abstract: EVALUATES PERFORMANCE OF CONSORTIUM FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (CID) IN ASSISTING NIGER CEREALS PROJECT (NCP) FROM 7/1/75 TO 12/11/76. CID HIRED TO HELP PROVIDE GOVT OF NIGER (GON) WITH A NATIONAL CAPABILITY IN THE PRODUCTION, DISTRIBUTION, AND MARKETING OF SORGHUM & MILLET. CID EVAL TEAM HELD DISCUSSIONS WITH GON OFFICIALS & STAFF MEMBERS OF USAID & NCP. NATL AGR RESEARCH INSTITUTE (INRAN) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE DEVEL OF A PROVEN SET OF PRODUCTN INCREASING PRACTICES,THROUGH VARIETAL IMPROVEMENT,AGRONOMIC RESEARCH RELATED TO SORGHUM & MILLET,AND WORKABLE SYSTEMS FOR DELIVERY OF MECHNIZATN TO FARMERS. EVALUATORS EXPRESSED A NEED FOR BETTER LIBRARY & LAB FACILITIES TO SUPPORT CEREALS RESEARCH & SOIL TESTING & ANALYSIS, & FOR THE CONSTRUCTN OF SEED RESEARCH & PRODUCTN CTRS WITH PARTICULAR EMPHASIS ON WATER CONSERVTN & IRRIGN SYSTEMS DESIGNED TO ENHANCE PRODUCTN. PERSONNEL NEED TRNG IN LAB TECHNIQUES & IN DEMONSTRATN,MAINTENANCE,& REPAIR OF ANIMAL TRACTR & OTHER TYPES OF FARM EQUIP. A LACK OF TRAINED MANPOWER IS A CRUCIAL PROBLEM IN THE SEED MULTIPLICTN & DISTRIBUTN COMPONENT. ACQUISITION OF EQUIP HAS BEEN SLOW,& DEVEL OF SEED MULTIPLICTN CTRS HAS BEEN HAMPERED BY INCREASED SHIPPING COSTS,AN INADEQUATE IRRIGATN SYSTEM,& DIFFICULTIES IN PROCURING INSECTICIDE. REQUISITE TO PROJECT SUCCESS IS THE ESTABLISHMT OF A SOUND NATL SEED POLICY. THE TEAM FEELS THAT DEVEL OF EFFECTIVE DELIVERY SYSTEMS DEPENDS ON COORDINATN AMONG CONCERNED AGENCIES, QUANTIFIED TARGETS,& A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH BY THE CID ADVISOR. THE NIGERIEN COOP & CREDIT ORGANIZATN(UNCC) HAS SEVERAL NEEDS: READILY AVAILABLE TRANSPORT; APPROPRIATE FACILITIES; PERSONNEL UPGRADING THROUGH IN-SERVICE SEMINARS; ECONOMIC VIABILITY STUDY; MORE FLEXIBLE FISCAL CONTROL; & USAID-GON POLICIES ASSURING NECESSARY INPUTS OF FERTILIZER,SEED MATERIALS,&EQUIP. AFTER REVIEWING SEVERAL MEMORANDA,TEAM RECOMMENDS THAT USAID PURSUE PROPOSAL TO ORGANIZE VILLAGE DIESEL MILLS TO GRIND  MILLET & EXTRACT PEANUT OIL,THEREBY FREEING WOMEN TO PARTICIPATE IN VILLAGE INDIGO-DYE INDUSTRIES.

Abstract: BACKGROUND PAPER ASSESSES NIGERIEN COOP & CREDIT ORGANIZATION (UNCC) & GOVT OF NIGER (GON) EFFORTS TO INCREASE CEREAL PRODUCTION, BASED ON NATIONAL & REGIONAL DOCUMENTS & TAPED INTERVIEWS WITH FARMERS & NIGERIEN LOCAL-LEVEL CADRE. A QUESTIONNAIRE WAS DEVELOPED & ADMINISTERED IN 5 VILLAGES; DATA NOT YET COMPILED. 3 AGRICULTURAL EXTENSION MODLES ARE DISCUSSED. THE 1ST IS COMPOSED OF A PROFESSIONAL AGRICULTURAL STAFF WITH A NETWORK OF PEASANT DEMONSTRATORS ELECTED BY VILLAGE MUTUAL COOPS. INADEQUATE TRAINING OF DEMONSTRATORS HAS RESULTED IN LOW FARMER RECEPTIVITY. IN ADDITION, FERTILIZER IS DIFFICULT TO OBTAIN ONCE FARMERS HAVE BEEN INTERESTED. MODEL II EMPLOYS AIDE-ENCADEURS WHO UNFORTUNATELY ARE USUALLY SELECTED ON THE BASIS OF FORMAL SCHOOLING AND/OR PERSONAL CONTACTS RATHER THAN ACTUAL KNOWLEDGE & SOCIAL ACCEPTABILITY. THEY DOLE-OUT LARGE AMOUNTS OF FREE FERTILIZER, IMPRESSING FARMERS WITH REMARKABLE RESULTS. MODEL III IS A VARIATION OF MODEL II,WITH AIDE-ENCADEURS CIRCULATED THROUGH VILLAGES IN A MULTITUDE OF JOBS. IN BOTH CASES, AIDE-ENCADEURS ARE POORLY TRAINED AND NOT WELL-SUPERVISED. TRAINING PROGRAMS WERE DEVISED FOR YOUNG FARMERS, BUT WERE ATTENDED MOSTLY BY SONS OF WEALTHY, INFLUENTIAL FAMILIES. PARTICIPANTS RECEIVED INCOMPLETE UNITS OF EQUIPMENT AND HAD NO SYSTEMATIC DEMONSTRATION ROLES. IN THE UNCC COOP STRUCTURE, MAJOR EMPHASIS WAS PUT ON MARKETING GROUPS, BUT FARMERS DISLIKED THE INCREASED EXPENDITURES OF TIME AND TRANSPORT. LOCAL-LEVEL COOPS REMAIN UNDER TRADITIONAL AUTHORITIES AND COOP EDUCATION EFFORTS HAVE BEEN MISDIRECTED. THE VOLUME OF LOANS AND THEIR SUBSEQUENT REPAYMENT IS GROWING STEADILY, BUT ACCORDING TO UNCC FIGURES DEFAULT IS VERY HIGH. LOAN RECORDS AT THE REGIONAL LEVEL HAVE BEEN FOUND TO BE INACCURATE, WHICH CASTS DOUBT ON THE ENTIRE SYSTEM.

Abstract: RECORDS NIGER NATIONAL CEREALS PROJECT EVALUATION MEETING ON 12/11/76 WITH OFFICIALS OF USAID, GOVT OF NIGER (GON), AND CONSORTIUM FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (CID). PURPOSE OF PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE GON WITH AN ECOLOGICALLY SUSTAINABLE AND REASONABLY PRICED CEREAL PRODUCTION AND DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM TO SERVE A LARGER POPULATION AT A SMALLER RATE PER CAPITA OF LAND CULTIVATION. THE MOST OUTSTANDING PROBLEM AREAS ARE DELAYS IN THE ORDERING AND DELIVERY OF EQUIPMENT AND MATERIALS AND DELAYS BY GON IN PAYMENT OF SALARIES AND IN PAYMENTS FOR EQUIPMENT AND SUPPLIES. THE NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH INSTITUTE(INRAN) SHOULD CONSTRUCT AND ORGANIZE ADDITIONAL RESEARCH SUBSTRUCTURES; DEVELOP ANIMAL TRACTION AND OTHER SIMPLE EQUIPMENT; CONSIDER AVAILABLE EXTENSION PERSONNEL IN PLANNING, EMPHASIZING TRAINING ACTIVITIES; AND DIVERSIFY ITS INVOLVEMENT IN THE PROJECT. AT THE SEED MULTIPLICATION CENTERS, SHORT-TERM CONSULTANTS ARE NEEDED TO SELECT AND PLACE OR DERS FOR CLEANING AND PROCESSING EQUIPMENT. LOCAL WORKERS MUST BE GATHERED AND TRAINED. A STRONG NATIONAL SEED POLICY IS REQUISITE TO PROJECT SUCCESS. A SPECIAL EFFORT SHOULD BE MADE IN THE ENSUING 6 MONTHS TO DEVELOP NEW EXTENSION TECHNIQUES REQUIRING LESS TRAINING; TO COORDINATE AND PERHAPS COMBINE EFOORTS; AND TO DECIDE WHETHER TO TRAIN AIDE-ENCADEURS AND WHERE TO PLACE THEM AT PROJECT TERMINATION. EVALUATORS HIGHLY RECOMMEND THAT THE EXTENSION ADVISOR BE CONCERNED WITH ALL ASPECTS OF EXTENSION. THE NIGERIEN COOPERATIVE AND CREDIT ORGANIZATION(UNCC) SHOULD BE EXPANDED TO INCLUDE A SPECIAL TRAINING CENTER, BUT THE PROJECT MUST INSURE THE SUPPLY OF ADEQUATE INPUTS AND A PROTECTED MARKET. FUNDING WILL BE INCREASED BY 30% FOR THE FOLLOWING YEAR.

Abstract: SUMMARIZES DISCUSSIONS HELD AT THE SEMINAR ON "NUTRITION POLICY IN ASIA" HELD IN PENANG, MALASIA FROM 6/7/76 TO 6/9/76. SEMINAR WAS SPONSORED BY THE SOUTHEAST ASIA DEVELOPMENT ADVISORY GROUP AND INCLUDED REPRESENTATIVES FROM PHILIPPINES, INDONESIA, THAILAND, AND THE US. SEMINAR PARTICIPANTS EVALUATED THE NUTRITIONAL ACTIVITIES IN THE PHILIPPINES, INDONESIA, THAILAND, AND PAKISTAN. IN THE PHILIPPINES, THE TIMBANG CHILD-WEIGHING PROGRAM (COVERING 50% OF ALL VILLAGES) HAS: (1) IDENTIFIED MALNDURISHED CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES, (2) HELPED FORM COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, AND (3) CREATED AN AWARENESS OF MALNUTRITION PROBLEMS AT LOCAL LEVELS BY SENSITIZING DECISION MAKERS AND EDUCATING THE POPULATION. THE GOP HAS ALSO SUCCEEDED IN REDUCING COCONUT OIL PRICES BY REPLACING TIN CANS WITH BOTTLES OR SELLING OIL IN BULK TO CONSUMERS WITH THEIR OWN CONTAINERS. IN INDONESIA, THE GOI IS MAKING PROGRESS IN SALT IODIZATION AND APPLIED NUTRITION. MAJOR CONCERN IS FOOD ADULTERATION, ESPECIALLY OF MILK WHICH IS BEING SOLD IN PLASTIC BAGS. IN THAILAND, PROBLEMS HAVE RESULTED FROM UNQUALIFIED OFFICIALS IN THE MINISTRY OF HEALTH, LACK OF CONSENSUS AS TO WHAT CONSTITUTED A NUTRITION PROGRAM, AND LIMITED ACTIVITY DURING THE 1960'S. ALSO, DUE TO THE LACK OF GOVERNMENT SUPPORT, NUTRITION CENTERS WERE LOCATED IN ECONOMICALLY AVERAGE VILLAGES RATHER THAN IN POORER ONES. THAILAND'S MOST SUCCESSFUL PROGRAMS INCLUDE MEAT SUBSTITUTES FABRICATED FROM MUNG BEAN PROTEIN (A BY-PRODUCT OF MUNG BEAN NOODLE PRODUCTION), SALT IODIZATION, AND DISSEMINATION OF HEALTH INFORMATION BY VILLAGE VOLUNTEERS. PAKISTAN HAS BEEN UNABLE TO CONVINCE ALL BUT ITS POOREST POPULATION TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF ITS FREE WHOLE WHEAT FLOUR PROGRAM SINCE LOW GRADE IMPORTED WHEAT IS USED AND PROCESSED IN A METHOD UNATTRACTIVE TO LOCAL POPULATIONS. SEMINAR PARTICIPANTS CONCLUDE THAT SUCCESSFUL NUTRITION PROGRAMS REQUIRE HIGH LEVELS OF POLICY COORDINATION, WORKERS WITH CAREER COMMITMENT TO NUTRITION, ADEQUATE RESOURCES FURNISHED TO NUTRITION WORKERS, AND AN ABILITY TO IDENTIFY AND SOLVE PROBLEMS.

Abstract: THIS IS AN OVERALL EVAL OF $3.9 MILLION 1972-76 LOAN TO STRENGTHEN INCAE IN NICARAGUA ACADEMICALLY AND FINANCIALLY. EVAL, PREPARED FOR ROCAP, GUATEMALA, WAS BASED ON STUDY OF BACKGROUND MATERIALS, FIELD VISITS TO INCAE, INTERVIEWS WITH CA GOVT, BUSINESS OFFICIALS, DISCUSSIONS WITH ROCAP. EVAL NOTE  MAJOR INCAE ACADEMIC GROWTH UNDER LOAN (FACULTY, ENROLLMENT,PROG QUALITY) BUT CENTERS ATTENTION ON PROJ PURPOSE OF ENSURING INCAE'S LONG-TERM FINANCIAL VIABILITY. LATTER HAS NOT BEEN ACHIEVED. PROJ STRATEGIES FOR THIS (ACHEIVING ECONOMIES OF SCALE, DEVELOPMENT OF INCAE CONSULTING BUSINESS, STUDENT LOAN FUND, INCREASED FUND RAISING) HAVE PROVEN UNREALISTIC,INEFFECTIVE. ELEMENTS OF INCAE NOT ORIGINALLY GRASPED AS CONTRIBUTORY TO ITS COSTLINESS ARE: SCOPE OF ITS PROGRAMS (MODELLED ON HARVARD BUS SCHL), TEACHER-STUDENT RATIO (40-175), FULL RESIDENCE REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL STUDENTS, CASE METHOD OF INSTRUCTION, HIGH PERSONNEL TURNOVER, HIGH COST OF FUNDRAISING, COMPLEXITY OF MANAGEMENT, AND ESP  LACK OF ENDOWMENT AND OF FIXED ANNUAL SUPPORT. INCAE HAS OPERATED WITH DEFICIT SINCE ITS INCEPTION (1964). CUMULATIVE DEFICIT UNDER AID LOANS (1970-76) IS $1.5 MIL  AND TOTAL DEBT IS $4.5 MIL. PROBLEMSWILL WORSEN IN NEXT 2 YEARS, EVEN MORE WHEN LOAN REPAYMENT  COMES DUE IN 1983. YET BECAUSE OF EXCELLENCE, IMPORTANCE IN CA, INCAE MUST BE SALVAGED. TO THIS END EVAL RECOMMENDS: 1) COST REDUCTION PROG IN INCAE PROGRAMS, FACULTY AND CLOSE MONITORING OF COSTS; 2) GENERATION OF NEW REVENUE BY E.G., SMALL SEMINARS, IMPROVED FUNDRAISING FOR PRIVATE SECTOR, REASSESSMENT BY BRD OF DIRECTORS OF ATTITUDES TO CA GOVT AID: 3) THAT BOARD BECOME MORE FINANCIALLY KNOWLEDGEABLE OF INCAE AND INSIST OF FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY; AND 4) THAT BOARD ASSESS AT ONCE AND DEVELOP STRATEGY FOR INCAE'S LONG-TERM FINANCIAL NEEDS OF PERMANENT CAPITAL ($3-4 MIL)  AND FIXED ANNUAL INCOME, ESP  IN VIEW OF FUTURE LOAN REPAYMENT. EVAL CONCLUDES BY STATING THAT STRUCTURAL CHANGES IN INCAE MAY BE NECESSARY.  LARGE PACKAGE OF BACKGROUND MATERIALS IS APPENDED TO EVALUATION.

Abstract: THIS EX-POST EVALUATION WAS PART OF A LARGER PROJECT WHICH WILL COMPARE HEALTH PROGRAMS IN AT LEAST SIX COUNTRIES. THE EVALUATORS AGREED THAT THE BASIC PROJECT PURPOSE -- INCREASING PUBLIC HEALTH KNOWLEDGE AND THUS IMPROVING PUBLIC HEALTH STATUS -- WAS NOT SATISFACTORILY ACHIEVED. THERE WERE MANY INADEQUACIES IN THIS PROJECT. THE PROGRAM WAS WEAK ADMINISTRATIVELY FROM THE POINT OF VIEW OF COORDINATION WITH HOST GOVERNMENTS, WITH OTHER DONOR AGENCIES AND INTERNAL MANAGEMENT. NOR WAS A REALISTIC STRATEGY PROVIDED AS TO WHAT COULD/SHOULD BE ACCOMPLISHED IN THE AID TIME FRAME GIVEN THE RESOURCES AVAILABLE. ALTHOUGH THE PROJECT DESIGN WAS SUPPOSED TO ALLOW IT TO BE REPLICATED ELSEWHERE, IT WAS TOO RESOURCE INTENSIVE TO ALLOW FOR WIDESPREAD IMPLEMENTATION. ADMINISTRATIVE PROBLEMS WERE EXACERBATED BY (1) POORLY DEFINED LINES OF RESPONSIBILITY AMONG AID, OCEAC (ORGANIZATION FOR THE CONTROL OF ENDEMIC DISEASES IN CENTRAL AFRICA), AND THE CONTRACT PERSONNEL, AND (2) THE LACK OF A SUITABLE DATA BASE. THE PROBLEM OF IMPLEMENTING THE HEALTH EDUCATION PROGRAM, THE MOST CRUCIAL COMPONENT OF THE PROJECT, REFLECTED THE INADEQUACIES OF ADMINISTRATION AND DATA COLLECTION. IN THE SELECTION OF CANDIDATES FOR ADVANCED TRAINING HEALTH EDUCATION, LITTLE EFFORT WAS EXPENDED IN DETERMINING WHO WOULD BE THE MOST APPROPRIATE CANDIDATES, WHAT TYPE OF TRAINING WOULD MEET THE NEEDS OF THE RESPECTIVE COUNTRIES, WHERE THIS TRAINING COULD BEST BE OBTAINED OR WHETHER, IN RETROSPECT, THE EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE HAD BEEN EFFECTIVE. WITH REFERENCE TO TRAINING MATERIALS, THERE WAS A LACK OF SIMPLE, AVAILABLE, PORTABLE MATERIALS IN THE LOCAL LANGUAGE. IN THE REALM OF HEALTH DELIVERY, A SERIOUS GAP DEVELOPED BETWEEN THE TRAINING OF HEALTH EDUCATORS AND THE TRANSFER OF THEIR INFORMATION TO THE RURAL POPULATION. THIS PROBLEM WAS REFLECTED IN THE ORIGINAL AID/OCEAC PROJECT DESIGN AND RESOURCE ALLOCATION WHICH NEGLECTED THE DELIVERY COMPONENT.

Abstract: THE BENEFITS DERIVED BY AID FROM THE LEAGUE FOR INTERNATIONAL FOOD EDUCATION (LIFE) AND THE NATIONAL ACADEMY FOR SCIENCES/COMMITTEE ON INTERNATIONAL NUTRITION (NAS/CIN) ARE MORE THAN COMMENSURATE WITH THE RESOURCES INVESTED. THE WORLDWIDE DISTRIBUTION OF LIFE'S COMMUNICATION NETWORK INVOLVES CLIENTS WORKING ON ALL LEVELS OF NUTRITION DEVELOPMENT. LIFE HAS BEEN CREDITED WITH PROVIDING SIGNIFICANT ASSISTANCE IN SOLVING MALNUTRITION PROBLEMS. THE EFFORTS AND SUPPORT OF NAS/CIN TO AID'S NUTRITION STRATEGY HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO A NUMBER OF KEY ISSUES IN SOLVING PROBLEMS OF MALNUTRITION. THE UTILIZATION OF THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDED BY LIFE HAS HAD A SUBSTANTIAL IMPACT ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF PROJECTS TO SOLVE MALNUTRITION PROBLEMS AND HAS COVERED A BROAD RANGE OF TOPICS AND ISSUES IN INTERNATIONAL NUTRITIONAL PROGRAMS. LIFE HAS DIRECTLY ASSISTED IN THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF SPECIFIC PROJECTS TO SOLVE MALNUTRITION PROBLEMS IN LESSER DEVELOPED COUNTRIES (LDCS). GENERALLY, LIFE WAS VIEWED BY THOSE WHO RECEIVED DIRECT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND BY THOSE ON THE LIFE  NEWSLETTER MAILING LIST AS AN IMPORTANT SOURCE OF TECHNICAL INFORMATION AND ASSISTANCE. THE LIFE NEWSLETTER WAS CONSIDE RED TO BE ONE OF THE FEW SOURCES OF INFORMATION ON THE LATEST DEVELOPMENTS IN FOOD TECHNOLOGY; IT IS WIDELY CIRCULATED IN THE NUTRITION COMMUNITY. DESPITE THE SIGNIFICANT INFLUENCE WHICH IT IS EXERTING ON SOLVING PROBLEMS OF MALNUTRITION AND FOOD TECHNOLOGY FOR VARIOUS CLIENTS IN LDCS, THERE IS EVIDENCE THAT LIFE HAS AN EVEN GREATER POTENTIAL IN ASSISTING LDCS TO RESOLVE THEIR PROBLEMS IN NUTRITIONAL DEVELOPMENT. THE EVALUATORS FINDINGS WERE BASED ON A MAIL SURVEY AND FIELD VISITS TO SRI LANKA, INDIA, COLOMBIA AND HONDURAS. THEY MADE 7 RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVING THE CONTRIBUTION OF LIFE AND NAS/CIN.

Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT TO ESTABLISH RURAL ELECTRIC COOPERATIVES TO SERVE THE INHABITANTS OF RURAL NORTH CENTRAL NICARAGUA. EVALUATION, A LOAN COMPLETION REPORT, COVERS A PERIOD ENDING 6/30/76. NEITHER THE STARTING-POINT OF THE EVALUATION NOR ITS METHODOLOGY ARE INDICATED. THE EMPRESA NACIONAL DE LUZ Y FUERZA (ENALUF), A PUBLIC POWER UTILITY OWNED BY THE GOVERNMENT OF NICARAGUA, IS IMPLEMENTING THE PROJECT. MAJOR PROJECT ACHIEVMENT TO DATE HAS BEEN THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A NEW RURAL ELECTRIC COOPERATIVE FOR THE SEGOVIAS (CODERSE). CODERSE'S DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM IS IN PLACE AND OVER 24,000 PEOPLE ARE NOW CONNECTED TO THE SYSTEM. THIRTY MILES OF 69KV TRANSMISSION LINE; A 5,000KVA SUB-STATION; 410 MILES OF 14.4/24.9KV DISTRIBUTION LINES; AND 280 MILES OF 120/240 VOLT SECONDARY LINES AND SERVICE INSTALLATIONS WERE CONSTRUCTED. THE PROJECT WAS DELAYED NINE MONTHS BY THE FAILURE OF A GUATEMALAN SUPPLIER TO DELIVER POLES AND CROSSARMS AS CONTRACTED. LOAN FUNDS WERE USED TO PURCHASE TOOLS, POLES, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FROM THE NATIONAL ELECTRIC COOPERATIVE ASSOCIATION (NRECA), INCLUDING ASSISTANCE NOT ORIGINALLY PLANNED FOR IN THE AREAS OF RATE STUDY, ACCOUNTING, EVALUATION OF POLE AND MATERIAL QUALITY, AND ADMINISTRATION. THE TRAINING COMPONENT, HOWEVER, HAS FALLEN FAR SHORT OF STATED OBJECTIVES. GENERAL MANAGEMENT OF OPERATIONS MUST BE UPGRADED. A CONTINUING TRAINING PROGRAM SHOULD BE IMPLEMENTED AT THE FIELD OPERATIONS LEVEL. AID HAS AUTHORIZED A GRANT AGREEMENT WITH THE NATIONAL ENERGY INSTITUTE (NEI) TO PROVIDE SUCH TRAINING. THE PROJECT LOAN ALSO FINANCED THE EXPANSION OF FOUR EXISTING RURAL COOPERATIVES, ENABLING THEM TO PROVIDE ELECTRICITY TO AN ADDITIONAL 4,700 CUSTOMERS. (APPROXIMATELY 22,000 FAMILIES ARE SERVED BY THESE COOPERATIVES.) IT IS CONCLUDED THAT A STRONG RURAL ELECTRIC NETWORK, SERVING OVER 150,000 PEOPLE AND A NUMBER OF IMPORTANT AGRO-INDUSTRIES AND LARGE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS, HAS BEEN DEVELOPED. ALTHOUGH IT WAS ANTICIPATED THAT THE MAJOR IMPACT OF THE PROJECT WOULD FALL ON THE MIDDLE INCOME FARMER, THE RURAL POOR ALSO BENEFITTED FAR BEYOND EXPECTATIONS.

Abstract: EVALUATES LOAN PROJECT WITH THE GOVERNMENT OF PERU TO ASSIST IN THE REHABILITATION OF THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR IN THE AREA AFFECTED BY THE EARTHQUAKE OF 5/31/70. THIS USAID LOAN COMPLETION REPORT COVERS THE ENTIRE PROJECT FROM 7/25/72 TO 10/31/74. THE EVALUATION WAS BASED ON DISCUSSIONS WITH AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT BANK (AGBANK) OFFICIALS, VISITS TO SEVERAL SUBPROJECTS, SELECTIVE REVIEW OF SUB-BORROWER CARDS AND FILES, AND REVIEW OF AGBANK DOCUMENTS. THE LOAN FUNDS WERE TO PROVIDE MEDIUM-TERM CREDITS AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO SMALL AND MEDIUM FARMERS, EITHER FARMING INDIVIDUAL PLOTS OR ORGANIZED INTO ASSOCIATIVE ENTERPRISES, IN ORDER TO REPLACE CAPITAL LOSSES AND RESTORE THE DISASTER-VICTIMIZED PRODUCTION CAPACITY OF THESE UNITS. IN THIS RESPECT, THE LOAN HAS BEEN SUCCESSFUL. MOST SUB-LENDING OCCURRED IN THE COASTAL AREAS OF AGRARIAN ZONE III (TRUJILLO, CHIMBOTE AND CASMA) AND AGRARIAN ZONE IV (HUACHO, HUARAL AND LIMA). SPECIFIC SUB-LOAN ACTIVITIES INCLUDED: HOUSING, BRIDGE, AND RIVER DEFENSE (RE)CONSTRUCTION; PLANTING PEACH TREES AND GRAPE VINES; AND PURCHASING FARM MACHINERY, FERTILIZERS, INSECTICIDES, AND CATTLE. ALL $5 MILLION IN LOAN FUNDS WERE DISBURSED. THE MAJOR PROBLEMS ENCOUNTERED INCLUDED VERY LATE RESOLUTION OF A DUAL ADMINISTRATION PROBLEM INVOLVING THE MINISTRY OF AGRICULTURE AND THE AGBANK, RESULTING IN HIGH DEFAULT RATES. MANY PARTICIPATING SMALL FARMERS RECEIVED LITTLE OR NO ADVICE FROM EXTENSION AGENTS BECAUSE OF MANPOWER SHORTAGES AND TRANSPORTATION DEFICIENCIES. RAPID CHANGES IN THE LAND TENURE SYSTEM BROUGHT ABOUT BY THE AGRARIAN REFORM OFTEN PRECLUDED GRANTING OF CREDIT, WITH THE MOST RECURRENT INSTANCES INVOLVING THE LACK OF LEGAL STATUS OF THE APPLICANT. FINALLY, AGBANK SUB-LOAN CONTROL AND AUDITING PROCEDURES AND PRACTICES WERE OFTEN DEFICIENT. A DETAILED REPORT HAS BEEN SUBMITTED TO THE AGBANK OUTLINING SPECIFIC MEASURES TO CORRECT THESE DEFICIENCIES. AN ESTIMATED 5,500 FARM FAMILIES DIRECTLY BENEFITTED FROM THE CREDIT PROGRAM, SIGNIFICANTLY EXCEEDING INITIAL PROJECTIONS OF 3,500. THIS WAS MADE POSSIBLE BY THE GREATER RELIANCE ON GROUP LENDING THROUGH ASSOCIATIVE ENTERPRISES THAN PLANNED.

Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT TO ASSIST THE GOVERNMENT OF PERU (GOP) IN RECONSTRUCTION EFFORTS IN THE AREAS AFFECTED BY THE 1972 EARTHQUAKE AND THE 1970 FLOOD. EVALUATION COVERS THE PERIOD FROM 8/75 TO 3/23/76. NO METHODOLOGY IS INDICATED. (4) MONTHLY "VALORIZATION" SHOULD BE PROMPT AND MORE DETAILED AND A REPORT ON CONSTRUCTION PROGRESS SHOULD BE ON TIME AND INCLUDE THE INSPECTOR'S SUMMARY. (5) THE AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS TO MEET COST INCREASES SHOULD BE DETERMINED AND, IF REQUIRED, FUNDS SHOULD BE RAISED OR THE NUMBER OF PROJECTS REDUCED.

Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT IN HONDURAS TO RECONSTRUCT PRIMARY SCHOOLS DAMAGED BY HURRICANE FIFI TO 1974 AND TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF RURAL PRIMARY EDUCATION. THE EVALUATION COVERS THE PERIOD 3/75 TO 12/76. NO METHODOLOGY IS INDICATED. A TOTAL OF 194 CLASSROOMS WERE CONSTRUCTED AND 64 SCHOOLS REPAIRED, THUS COMPLETING RECONSTRUCTION OF ALL DAMAGED SCHOOLS AND PROVIDING FACILITIES FOR 27,000 STUDENTS. THE SCHOOLS ARE FUNCTIONAL, DURABLE, AND IN MANY CASES A CONSIDERABLE IMPROVEMENT ON PREVIOUS FACILITIES. CARE WAS CONTRACTED TO REBUILD AND REPAIR SMALL SCHOOLS (SIX CLASSROOMS AND UNDER), PRIVATE FIRMS FOR THE REMAINDER. THE MINISTRY OF EDUCATION (MOE) EXPANDED A RECENT PROGRAM EMPHASIZING AGRICULTURAL AND VOCATIONAL ASPECTS OF THE CURRICULUM. THE PROGRAM SHOULD INCREASE RETENTION RATES, KEEP CHILDREN IN SCHOOL LONGER, AND ENGENDER BETTER RELATIONS WITH PARENTS AND THE COMMUNITY. TO SUPPORT THE NEW CURRICULUM, TRADITIONALLY SCARCE SCHOOL SUPPLIES, E.G., MAPS, SCIENCE EQUIPMENT, AND TOOLS, WERE PROVIDED, AS WERE ONE-MONTH IN-SERVICE TRAINING COURSES (COSTING ONLY $300 EACH) FOR 3,400 TEACHERS. TRAINING COURSES WERE CONDUCTED BY THE SUPERVISORY DEPARTMENT OF PRIMARY EDUCATION AND WERE WELL RECEIVED. SCHOOL CONSTRUCTION WAS DELAYED BEYOND THE PLANNED ONE YEAR BY HEAVY RAINS AND BY FUNDING TO CARE INSUFFICIENT TO PROVIDE FOR SIMULTANEOUS CONSTRUCTION OF ALL BUILDINGS. PROCUREMENT OF EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS WAS DELAYED BY SLOW ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES AND THE MOE'S DECISION TO FUND MATERIALS ONLY AFTER FURNITURE COSTS WERE DETERMINED. AS A RESULT, $48,000 IN LOAN FUNDS WERE NOT DISBURSED. THE HOST GOVERNMENT WILL FUND THIS AMOUNT. THERE WERE ALSO DIFFICULTIES IN WORKING WITH CARE. ITS CONTRACT WAS NEGOTIATED ONLY AFTER ITS UNREASONABLE FEE REQUEST WAS REDUCED AND MANY OF ITS REIMBURSEMENT REQUESTS NEEDED REVISION. THERE WERE ALSO INADEQUACIES IN SEVERAL CARE CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS, ALTHOUGH THESE WERE CORRECTED. AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT, THE MOE WILL BE ABLE TO PROVIDE NECESSARY SCHOOL MAINTENANCE AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS. THROUGH ANOTHER AID LOAN, MOE WILL CONTINUE IN-SERVICE TEACHER TRAINING.

Abstract: EVALUATES LOAN TO THE GOVERNMENT OF PERU (GOP) FOR THE AGRIBUSINESS SECTOR TO ESTABLISH A PRIVATE INVESTMENT FUND (PIF). EVALUATION, A LOAN COMPLETION REPORT, COVERS THE PERIOD 4/25/68 TO 4/15/76 AND IS BASED IN PART ON VISITS TO BENEFICIARIES. IN 10/68 A MILITARY GOVERNMENT TOOK CONTROL OF PERU, REVERSED THE FORMER REGIME'S PRIORITIES, AND ACCORDED THE PRIVATE SECTOR THE LOWEST PLACE. THIS, PLUS THE CONTINUAL REORGANIZATION OF THE ORIGINAL IMPLEMENTING AGENCY, THE CENTRAL BANK, RESULTED IN ONLY FIVE SUBPROJECTS BEING FINANCED 1968-71. ONLY ONE COMMERCIAL BANK PARTICIPATED DUE TO THE LOW INTEREST RATES ESTABLISHED UNDER THE LOAN AND THE COMPLEXITY AND RIGIDITY OF LOAN OPERATING PROCEDURES. ALTHOUGH A 1972 USAID-FINANCED STUDY SHOWED THAT AMPLE DEMAND FOR LOAN FUNDS EXISTED, IT WAS NOT UNTIL TRANSFER OF IMPLEMENTATION RESPONSIBILITY TO THE GOP'S DEVELOPMENT FINANCE CORPORATION (COFIDE, ESTABLISHED 1972) THAT SUBLENDING RECOMMENCED. EVEN THEN PROGRESS WAS SLOWED BY PROCESSING BOTTLENECKS, ESPECIALLY REGARDING LOAN ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA AND BY COFIDE'S FAILURE TO COMMIT SUFFICIENT FUNDS TO APPROVED SUBPROJECTS. ONE SUBPROJECT HAD TO BE CANCELLED. AS A RESULT OF ALL THESE FACTORS, 80% OF LOAN FUNDS WERE DEOBLIGATED. ONLY $1.5 MILLION OF ORIGINALLY ALLOCATED $7.5 MILLION WAS ULTIMATELY DISBURSED. GOP DISBURSED $1.8 MILLION OF THE SAME AMOUNT ALLOCATED. NINE SUBPROJECTS WERE FINANCED. OF THE FOUR SUBPROJECTS VISITED, THE TWO FOR PURCHASING AIRCRAFT -- ONE TO TRANSPORT PASSENGERS AND BEEF, THE OTHER FOR A FUMIGATION SERVICE FOR AGRARIAN REFORM FARMERS -- WERE DOING WELL, ESPECIALLY THE FORMER. A THIRD SUBPROJECT, A FEEDER MILL, EXPERIENCED ADMINISTRATIVE PROBLEMS AND HAD TO OBTAIN A LOAN FROM THE INDUSTRIAL BANK TO REPAY THE PIF; WHILE A FOURTH, A PRODUCER OF VETERINARIAN PRODUCTS, HAS FALLEN IN ARREARS WITH PIF PAYMENTS. OF OTHER SUBPROJECTS, TWO ARE ALSO IN ARREARS, BUT PAYMENTS ARE BEING MADE BY INTERMEDIATE CREDIT INSTITUTIONS. USAID WILL CONTINUE TO MONITOR LOAN AGREEMENT COVENANTS REGARDING CONTINUING COOPERATION, TAXATION, DISCLOSURE OF MATERIALS, MAINTENANCE AND AUDIT OF RECORDS, AND INSPECTIONS.

Abstract: Evaluates project to assist the Government of the Dominican Republic (GODR) to use videotape technology to bring technical knowledge to small farmers. This special evaluation, whose time frame is unspecified, is based on onsite visits and interviews with USAID, GODR and Ideas, Inc. personnel, and farmer beneficiaries. The project was successful. At least 21 videotape presentations were conducted for use in:  (1) vocational education center programs; (2) farmer education; (3) technician education; (4) support to extension services; (5) recording one-time education experiences; (6) recruitment; and (7) documentation for official and public awareness.  These materials reached a total of 31,397 rural people from 179 communities, who responded well to them and applied knowledge acquired through their use. Twenty-five people were trained in the use of videotape recording technology and in the preparation of audiovisual and other materials during two five-month training programs  Several other small-scale workshop training programs were held and peer training occurred sporadically. The modified Foxfire approach (an approach in which students document a community problem and then work with experts in preparing a video message containing a potential solution for community residents) was used in at least one case. Although this approach, the proposed major thrust of the program, was a successful innovation, it was discontinued due to the loss of two educational institutions from the program.  Since the approach depended on student availability, there were no other formal schools involved in the program. Problems were observed in the areas of coordination of video production, transportation, evaluation, and program expansion. Recommendations were made as follows:  (1) officially acknowledge program integration; (2) equitably transfer video units; (3) strengthen leadership; (4) document project participants' acquired knowledge on videotape; (5) establish maintenance equipment funding; (6) reinstate the modified Foxfire approach; and (7) update training materials.

Abstract: Evaluates project to construct a 238 km class two highway between Tarapoto and Rio Nieva in Peru.  Evaluation covers the period from 1/75 to 3/76.  No evaluation methodology is indicated. The loan was reactivated on 1/10/75 after an interruption between 1969-74, due in part to a change in administration of the Government of Peru (GOP). The GOP delayed six to eight months replacing the Chief of Party (CP) and three engineers from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MTC), whose poor management has delayed construction. Under a new CP, construction has accelerated since the last quarter of 1974.  A major problem has been delays by MTC's Lima Headquarters in procuring equipment and spare parts.  As a result, only $3.058 million of $9.49 million reactivated funds has been disbursed.  It should be noted that although the GOP has already contributed $1 million to the project, it will have to contribute another $2 million if the project is to be completed satisfactorily. AID/W backstopping has generally been satisfactory.  Performance of the heavy equipment specialist, the USAID contract project monitor, and of local labor, has been excellent. MTC has investigated bridge foundations at three problem sites, but has yet to provide a comprehensive study of landslides, which continue to threaten completed road sections.  Construction progress has been satisfactory, and its technical quality is very good.  Due to the inaccessibility of the area, costs are comparatively high.  A final survey of centerline and road design were recently completed.  Still to be completed are:  clearing of 7 kms of construction area; excavation of 15 1/2 kms of jungle mountain terrain; placing of culverts and construction headwalls; construction of seven bridges (five should be completed by 12/77); 33 kms of final shaping of the roadbed; 79 kms of subbase; and 120 kms of course and final road improvement. If commodities arrive by 9-10/76 (MTC/Lima has begun procurement), and the Army Construction Company lends assistance, all loan funds could be disbursed by the terminal disbursement date of 12/31/77.

Abstract: Evaluates project to assist activities of the Population Council (PC).  This special evaluation covers the period 1973-1975 and is based on interviews with personnel from A.I.D. and PC. PC conducted 50 subgrants and 13 in-house projects between 10/73 and 12/75.  In addition, PC pioneered two new approaches to family planning delivery, urban hospital-based postpartum programs and rural mother child health/family planning projects. Despite its fulfillment of the terms of the contract, there has been a growing sense of dissatisfaction with PC.  PC and A.I.D. have been collaborators since A.I.D. entered the population field in 1965. However, as the Office of Population gained experience, it became less willing to let PC follow its own priorities when using A.I.D. funds.  In turn, PC renewed its determination not to permit outside control of its programs.  Serious professional and technical differences also occurred.  For example, while PC stressed the importance of continuation rates of acceptors in evaluating projects, A.I.D. considered the number, age, and parity of acceptors more significant.  In addition, PC favored IUD's, while A.I.D. promoted oral contraceptives, sterilizaton and, for a time, menstrual regulation.  In addition, A.I.D. shifted its priorities from education, research, and fellowships to direct support of programs and supplies.  With regard to future collaboration, it is recommended that A.I.D.: (1) support the Population in Development Planning Program and collaborate with PC in making population data and issues an important element in development planning; (2) assist the International Committee on Applied Research in Population (ICARP) to evaluate and encourage sterilization techniques and delivery networks; (3) encourage PC to provide additional assistance to overseas information programs and to tailor its publications, especially translations, to local needs; (4) encourage PC to serve as an executing agent for the United Nations Family Planning Agency; and (5) encourage PC to include women, blacks, and non-U.S. citizens on its staff.

Abstract: Evaluates 11 small and medium land and water development projects in Korea completed in 1974.  Evaluation timeframe is not specified; methodology included interviews with 220 randomly selected farm households. Evaluation purpose is to assess changes in agricultural production and to compare actual with planned internal rates of return (IRR's) associated with these changes. In general, each project was designed to increase and/or improve paddy acreage.  The sample projects resulted in a per household increase in paddy area of .07 ha and in improvement in the ratio of fully irrigated to total paddy of 56.6 points.  Overall changes included the following:  the double cropping ratio increased from 135.6 to 148.5 %; the area devoted to the production of new high-yielding varieties (HYV's) increased 21.8% while that for the production of native rice declined 28.3%; labor inputs for Tongil rice and native varieties increased 2.1% and 3.7%, respectively, but declined 1.1% for barley; the transplanting date for rice was advanced from 9 to 15 days due to the more widespread cultivation of HYV's; and the quantity of chemical fertilizer used per 10 ha increased 16.4%.  Pure yield increases associated with the projects tended to be higher for rice and lower for barley than anticipated -- Tongil rice yields increased 17.4%; native rice, 35%; common barley, 7.5%; naked barley, 9.9%; and white potato yields, 11.7%.  While favorable, such changes may precipitate future problems affecting labor requirements, agricultural inputs (chemicals, machinery, information), and crop production. Among the many general and component-specific conclusions drawn are: Lack of sufficient information or inputs rather than poor irrigation facilities may account for why HYV's were adopted less in northern than in southern provinces.  Shifts in labor were especially acute--improvements in paddy acreage, drainage, and irrigation reduced labor required for plowing and water management activities and increased labor required for seed bed preparation and transplanting. Finally, the IRR's associated with the sampled areas are likely to be greater than planned.

Abstract: Evaluates documented response of Tulane University Technical Assistance Project, 8/75-3/76, to modifications of Phase 1 (Plan and Design) and Phase 2 (Implementation) of Research Program in Health Delivery Prototype Services (PRIMOPS) in Colombia.  This program was created to develop, implement, and evaluate health delivery system model providing wide coverage of services, including family planning, at reasonable cost to Ministry of Health, State of Valle, Health District of Cali. Phase 1 is essentially complete and satisfactory, except for refinement of design cost analysis study and lack of computer-programmer capabilities.  Tulane University has fulfilled its obligations to supprot and train three counterparts in PRIMOPS/Cali (PIC) in order to accomodate expansion of progrm to other areas.  Satisfactory consultation has been provided to PIC as requested in identifying problems and solutions. The model design for delivery of health objectives: rational patient flow to different health service providers, delegation of tasks to most efficient levels of service, and extension of health care and disease prevention to the home.  Model design is incomplete in measures for integrating training and supervision, and concern continues about quality of data collection, flow, cleaning, reduction, and analysis necessary for evaluation of program as a model. Indications are that projected simulation models would be invalid until data quality improves.  Evaluator recommends that hospital data be largely excluded from health system evaluation due to data flow constraints. Selections from Tulane University Report of 3/76 indicate a positive response to areas of concern expressed above, including integration of training and supervision, design of monitoring system, methodology for choosing control area and area profile, and evaluation of acceptance of health services and their effect on morbidity, mortality, and family planning.

Abstract: Evaluates project to rehabilitate small and medium enterprises in industry, services, and commerce which were victimized by the earthquake of 3/31/70 in Peru.  This loan completion report covers the period from the signing of the loan agreement (7/25/72) to final disbursement (12/31/75) and was based on visits to sub-borrowers and survey data. The loan was used to establish a fund (CRECE fund) in the Central Reserve Bank of Peru.  Sub-loans were granted for investment in the reconstruction of 106 small businesses and the development of 96 new enterprises.  Approximately 30 sub-loans were made to entrepreneurs (mostly individuals) involved in the production of goods or provision of services directly related to construction.  The project also resulted in at least doubling employment in CRECE-funded enterprises and in introducing sub-borrowers to the modern credit system.  Two patterns were noticed concerning repayment performance.  First, the overall record is significantly better in the sierra than on the coast.  Second, repayment performances of service enterprises were generally superior to those of industry. In aggregate terms, delinquency rates appear high compared to traditional commercial lending experience, but the record is quite respectable considering the nature of the project. Although project objectives were accomplished, success has been costly, both in direct per capita costs of credit and indirect administrative costs.  Unfortunately, it appears as if the institutional impact will not be a lasting one, which may be the cause of the current severe liquidity shortage in Peru or could reflect the lack of adequate commercial incentive inherent in this project. Finally, the technical and administrative performance of the new implementing agency, the regional office for the Development of the Earthquake Zone (ORDEZA), was less than optimal, owing to its conflicting and overburdening dual role in technical design and in credit approvals, and to the lack of personnel, policy, and organizational stability.  The CRECE fund will be used in the future to support cooperative enterprises.

Abstract: Evaluates, for the period 4/25/69 to 6/30/76, loan to the Central American (CA) Bank for Economic Integration (CABEI) to help CABEI to promote economic integration by financing infrastructure subprojects, especially in the public sector. Evaluation methodology is not indicated. Terminal Disbursement Date (TDD) was extended twice, to 3/31/76 and to 6/30/76, to permit subproject completion.  Loan agreement was amended l0/21/70 to permit procurement from Code 940 countries and to exclude CA Member Countries for loan purposes; and amended 4/10/74 to delete the paragraph on security assignment and add an article on CABEI's obligation to AID. Loan funds were used to finance construction and engineering supervision on 15 highways, one airport, an Atlantic Coast inland waterway, and two highway signal projects, all of which are complete. Construction of the Gotera/Perquin Highway in El Salvador, however, is only 80% complete due to heavy rains and contractor's need to do other Government of El Salvador priority work.  Completion is not expected before 6/30/77. To avoid a further TDD extension, it was agreed to transfer $1.1 million in construction completed under Loan 014 to Loan 008.  A report on each subproject is contained in CABEI's final report of 6/76. CABEI has fully complied with the Loan Agreement, including the special covenants on a $40 million guarantee by member countries of CABEI borrowings and on export diversification and tourism. SIECA and CABEI jointly financed "CA Manual of Maintenance of Highways" and also produced manuals on regional highway signs and signals and on loan control and vehicle dimensions. ROCAP and CABEI are currently conducting an ex-post benefit/cost analysis (scheduled for completion in 11/76) on several roads constructed under the program, with stress on their development impact. No problems are foreseen with CABEI's compliance with post-disbursement period covenants.  ROCAP will monitor loan amortization and will periodically report to AID/W on progress of the uncompleted subproject.

Abstract: Evaluates project to assist the Planned Parenthood Federation of America/Family Planning International Assistance (PPFA/FPIA) in institutionalizing and expanding the outreach of family planning (FP) services in LDC's.  Evaluation covers the period 2/1/75-4/12/76 and consists of an annual review by the A.I.D. Project Manager. FPIA's performance is improving and a recent AID-FPIA agreement will clarify FPIA's policy objectives.  FPIA has implemented the recommendations offered in the 2/75 evaluation and has improved its management of subgrants.  In addition, FPIA has demonstrated its ability to identify and develop innovative, cost-effective projects with LDC groups.  Nevertheless, communications between FPIA field and headquarter staff have been poor and problems exist concerning the timely submission of subproject proposals. FPIA's specific accomplishments include the following:  FPIA has emphasized service programs through the promotion/support of non-medical distribution of FP commodities and by encouraging the integration of voluntary sterilization, particularly minilaparotomy, into FP programs. Also it has developed FP projects with LDC women's organizations and increased its efforts to engender local support so as to minimize long-term dependence on FPIA funding.  FPIA is exploring ways to expand commodity distribution through church-related and other PVO channels. Also, FPIA has filled its technical staff positions, established field personnel in four LDC regions, and appointed a new project director. Efforts are underway to improve its communication network. Progress reports are now systematically answered by technical backstoppers in New York.  FPIA field personnel were also delegated greater responsibility in subgrant management, and subgrant proposals and disbursements are now issued in a more timely manner. Additional A.I.D. funds should be provided for FY 1976. Several recommendations to improve FPIA policy and management are also made, e.g., FPIA should continue to support PVO efforts in FP activities and further upgrade its management and administrative practices.

Abstract: THE PURPOSE OF THE EVALUATION IS TO EXAMINE AND COMPARE EXPERIENCE UNDER EDUCATION SECTOR LOANS TO DETERMINE THE IMPLICATIONS OF THAT EXPERIENCE FOR FUTURE ASSISTANCE TO EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN OTHER COUNTRIES, NOT TO APPRAISE THE SUCCESS OR FAILURE OF INDIVIDUAL PROGRAMS. THE MAJOR ELEMENTS OF THE HOST COUNTRY EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS SUPPORTED BY THE AID LOANS WERE VERY SIMILAR, INVOLVING MAJOR CHANGES IN CURRICULUM TO SUBSTITUTE A HIGHER VOCATIONAL CONTENT AND AN ORIENTATION TOWARD WORK INSTEAD OF ACADEMICS; TEACHER TRAINING; AND THE CONSTRUCTION AND EQUIPPING OF MULTI-PURPOSE SCHOOLS. IN CONTRAST TO THESE COMMON ELEMENTS, THE AID APPROACH IN SUPPORT OF SECTOR PROGRAMS DIFFERED SIGNIFICANTLY AMONG THE COUNTRIES. METHODS OF LOAN IMPLEMENTATION VARIED FROM COUNTRY TO COUNTRY WITH VARIATIONS DEPENDENT IN PART ON THE PURPOSES OF THE LOAN AND THE APPROACH TO SUPPORT OF THE SECTOR. THE NATURE AND EXTENT OF AID EVALUATION ALSO DIFFERED FROM COUNTRY TO COUNTRY. NO PROVISION WAS MADE UNDER ANY OF THE LOANS FOR EVALUATION AT THE PROJECT PURPOSE LEVELS AND BEYOND. SUFFICIENT TIME HAS NOT YET ELAPSED TO PERMIT AN APPRAISAL OF THE EFFECTS OF THE PROGRAMS UPON BROADER PURPOSES AND GOALS. THERE IS APPRECIABLE IMPROVEMENT IN THE NUMBER OF SCHOOLS BUILT, THE NUMBER OF CLASSROOMS PROVIDED, THE NUMBER OF TEACHERS AND OTHER EDUCATIONAL PERSONNEL TRAINED, BUDGETARY AND PAYMENT PROCEDURES, AND PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION PROCEDURES. THE EVALUATION CONTAINS CHAPTERS ON THE PROGRAMS; AID ANALYSIS; PROGRAM PHILOSOPHY, ASSUMPTIONS AND STRATEGY; METHODS OF IMPLEMENTATION AND EVALUATION; PROGRAM ACHIEVEMENTS; AND IMPLICATIONS FOR SECTOR APPROACH CONCEPTS. THE EVALUATORS MADE NINE RECOMMENDATIONS REGARDING SUCH MATTERS AS REDEFINING PURPOSES AND EXPECTATIONS OF THE SECTOR PROGRAMS, SETTING UP AN EVALUATION SYSTEM, RECONSIDERING THE ROLE AND NATURE OF SECTOR ASSESSMENTS, AND CONSIDERING ALTERNATIVES FOR DIFFERENT ASPECTS OF THE EDUCATION SECTOR PROGRAM.
